PREFATORY NOTE RELATING TO A CHANGE IN THE FORM OF THIS ILEPORT,

The Beport of the United States Coast and Geodetic Survey for the fiscal year 1891 is the first one in which the text was arranged for publication in two parts. P a r t I1 of that report, as well as P a r t I1 of the reports for the years 1802 atid 1803, mas published in octavo, while the quarto form mas retained for P a r t I. It was thought advantageous to publish both parts of this report for the year ending June 30,1894, in. quarto, and the change has accordingly been made. P a r t I contains the historical portion. It states the progress in field and office \vork, gives estimates for future progress, and a report of expenditures for the fiscal year. It is aucompanied by maps of general progress, and by progress sketches more i11 detail. P a r t I1 includes the professional papers relating to the ~nethods, discussions, :tnd results of the Survey which have been approved for publication during the year, such il1ustrations as are needed accompanying them. Part I being of less general inkrest than P a r t 11, in the future distribution of t,he Report Part I1 only will be sent, except in special cases. W. W. D U ~ J W ~ E ~ D , 8uperinte?iden2.

A P P E N D I X NO. 1-1894.

RELATIVE DETERMINATIONS OF GRAVITY WITH HALF-SECOND PENDULUMS, AND OTHER PENDULUM INVESTIGATIONS,

A REPOltT ON A GEOLOGIC EXAMINATION OF SOME COAST AND GEODETIC SURVEY GRAVITY STATIONS,
I3y G . K. GILBERT, GROLOQIBT,UNITED STATXBGEOLOGICAL SURVEY.

B l a n k page r e t a i n e d f o r p a g i n a t i o n

APPENDIX NO. 1-1894.
RELATIVE DETERMINATIONS OF GRAVITY WITH HALF-SECOND PENDULUM8, AND OTHER PENDULUM INVESTIGATIONS.

By O. R. P~;TNAJI, Amistnnt. Submittocl for publication January 23, 1895.

The following report includes the results of various investigations carried out by tlie writor undor the direction of Dr. T. C . Xendenhall. Tlleso are considered under the following heads: 1. Relative mo?surements of gravity a t twenty-six stations in tho United States. 1 1 . Observa. tions with quarter-second pondulums, and special 1,endulum investigations. 1 1 1 . Telegraphic comparisous between base stations in Washington, D. C. IV. Summary of the connections between American and European gravity stations by nloaris of relative 1)endnlum observations, and the reductioli of absolute determinations of gmrity to Washington. There is also included in this roport, as b e i ~ ~ intimately g connected wit11 tho other work described, (V) a translation of an illtcresting paper by Comrnandaut Defforges, of tlie '' Service. GBographiquev of France, giving an outline of the resnlts of his recent measurements in North America. A copy of this paper was sent tq tlio Supcrintende~itby Commandant Defforges, and i t has since been published* in France. The :~bsolute determination a t Washington was mado by order of General Durrbcagais, Director of the " Service Ofiogmphique," in courteous response to the request of the Superintendent, tho elaborate instrnmental o ~ ~ t fbeing it sent h w n Paris especially for this purpose. ' TIie writer desires to acknowledge his indebtedness to Mr.. C'. A. Schott, Mr. E. D. Preston, and Mr. 0. El. Tittmann, of tho Coast and Goodetic Survey, for their valnablc advice in colinoction with tho preparation of this report.
I.-RELATIVE MEASURISMENTS O F GRAVI'PY AT TWENTY-SIX STATlONS 1K TIIIS UNITED STATES.

Six of tliese doterlni~iations mere made a t various times iu the spring of 1894, and tho remaining twenty in a transcontinental series estending west from Washington to U t ; d (luring tlio summer of the same year, the whole forming the first extended series of gravity measnrements carried out in the United States. As shown on tlie accompanying map (fig.4), the greater part of tho st,ations are in the neighborliood of the thirty-iiintli parallel of latitude, following tlie gelleral course of tlie transcontinental triangulation ofthe Snrrey and including lnany of it's astronomically determined points. This lilie of gravity stations, commencing a t tho Atlantic coast, rises to near tlie crest of the Appalachian ridge, traverses the great smooth ceutral pli~in, inc:ressing in altitude gradually fro111 151 metres to 1.841 inotres; then risos to the high elevations of tlio main chain of tho Rocky Mountains, reaching an1 altitude of 4285 metres a t Pikes Peak, doscericis into tile eroded valleys of the Gr:u~dand Green rivers, crosses the summit of the IVasatch ridge, and finally descends to the great wcstern plateau of tho continent. The wide variety of orograpliic features thus tr:~vorsed so nearly in the same latitude makes this series peculiarly well aditptecl to throw light on tho continental variatiol~s of gravity, on the question of the proper method of reduction to sea Ievol, of utmost importance in c:ounection with tlie application of gravity n~casnrementsto the geodetic problem of the figure of the earth, as we11 as on tho questions of t,he llwturo rtlld condition of the --.. -- -. .- - . ... . . .. . -. *"Comptes Rondtls d u 1'Ac:tdbnlio tles Sciouces," Jnnuory 29, 1894.
9

10

m T I T E D STATES COAST AND GEODETIC SURVEY.

earth's crust. Several stations were included on account of peculiar features of their location, ad, for instance, three points in the Yellowstone Park, because here only in the United States summit of Pikes Peak was (exclusive of Alaska) are found tlie last signs of volcanic 'activity. T l ~ e occupied riot only for the sake of including a station of considerable altitude, but also because a comparison of this result wit11 that obtained a t Colorado Springs, near the base of the mountain, affords tlie data for coniputing the mean clensity of the earth. With the exception of Mor6, in India, this is the most elevated gravity station yet dctermincd with modern methods. Iiiciderltal to tho work, and as furnishing the most convenient facilities, observations wero in a number of instances inade a t educational institutions, which in return will receive desired information in regard to the relative value of an important physical constant. Thus also absolute xneasureme~its of gravity which may be carried out a t such institutions nlay be cou~parecl and ntilized elsewhere, and may bo referred to standard base stations for con~biuatiox~. Another and most i~nportant object contemplated in the recent work was to make a comparison of relative gravity results obtained with various kinds of apparatus arid diEerent lengths of pendulums. To this end there were inclucled four ststions visited by Commandant Defforges in 1893, who used a half-metre reversible pendulum. The two stations of Comlnandant Defforges on the Pacific Uoast had previously been determined by Dr. Meridenhall and Mr. Presto11 with the half-second (quarter-metre) invariable pendulnms, thus giving a comparison a t all of his stations in the United States. I n addition to the regular series of observations lnade a t each station of the past season with the Iialf-second pendulums, there was also carried along the quarter-second (onesixteenth metre) pendulum app:iratus designed by Dr. e end en hall and recently constructed. These pendulums were swung a t three stations, as well as a t Washington, before and after the trip. (See P a r t 11.) An interesting test of the wear of knife-edges, as well as of the accuracy of observation, was iriade by swinging the half-second pendulums (which carry a plane in the head and swing upon a knife-edge) upon 2x1 additional or standard edge a t Washington before and after the trip and a t two of the other stations. As the ordinary edge was in use four tirnes as long as the standard, valuable information was tlius o b t a i ~ ~ e on d the subject of wear. Further, tlie swings on the standard edge gave independent determinatiotis of gravity a t thest: stations, thus testixlg the reliability of tlie system of observi~lg. I n tho prosecution of this work the writer had the efficient assistance a t fifteen stations of Mr. 0.E. Mendenhall, Extra Observer, and a t three stations of Mr. S. B. Tinsley, Aid, while a t the remaining eight places tho work was conduoted without assistance. 111 selecting locations for the apparatus endeavor was made to obtain tho most Psvorablq conditiolls for observing, such as constant temperature, stable foundation for the l)ex~dulumcase, freedom from disturbing influences, and near proximity of the transit set up for time observations. To obtain such suitable places it was necessary to request the temporary nse of basement rooms or cellars in public or private buildings, or those belonging to corporations or colleges. These ratller unusual privileges were invariably grauted most freely and courteously, and i t is regretted that lack of space prevents the mentioning here of tho many persons who, by their kindliess in this respect or in the matter of furnishing valuable information and assistance, greatly aided the succe~sful prosecution of the work. Po8itio,z and description o f crtation8.-The latitudes and longitudes of the pendulum ~tlttions are mostly derived by connection with neighboring points whose geographical position had previously been determined by the Coast and Geodetic Survey or other good authority, either astronomically or geodetically. A t eight stations, Deer Park, Cleveland, Chicago, Lower Basin, Grand Canyon, Norris Basin, Pleasant Valley, aild Terre LIaute, the positions mere determined in connection with the pendulum work, the latitudes by observations on from two to four pairs of stars by Talcott's method, and the longitudes by transportation of two chronometers. The fact that a number of the other stations had been determined telegraphically gave a good opportunity of testing tho wcuracy of longitudes thus determined by carrying two chronoxneters on railway trains, and by other means of transportation. I 1 1 the seven cases where the chronometers were carried directly between telegraphic longitude stations tlie iliscordance between the telegraphic and the chronometric difference of longitudo ranges from 0.08 second (tirne) to 0.80 second, the average being 0.37 second, and the average distance traveled about 175 miles. The elevations are based on t l ~ e most accurate information available. For a majority of the

REPORT POlt 189A--PABT 11. interior stations they depend on the data given in Mr. Gannett's Dictionary of Altitudes in the United States. Additional information in regard to the elevation of Pikes Peak was furnished by Mr. Gannett. The elevations of the stations in the Yellomstone Park are based on information furnished by Maj. W. A. Jones, United States Engineers, from a line of levels run from Cinnabar, hlont. The pendulunl stations were in each case referred by hand level or otherwise to the railroad track, bench mark, or other known point. I n Inany casuv the writer is indebted to city engineers or college authorities for informamtion in regard to bench marks in the neighborhood of tlie station. The follo\ving (Table A ) is a brief description of the location of the pendulu~u stations and of the support for the pendulurn case a t each, together with the measured flexure of the case and support. Tho figures in the labt column represent the horizontal movelneut of the knife-edge when a force of 1.5 kilogramrnes was applied horizontally in the plane of oscillation. The latitudes, longitudes, and elevations will be found in Table E.

Instr?cments.-The apparatus used in the greater part of the work consisted of half-second pendulums, A 4, A 5, and A 6, witli the accolnpanyiiig air-tight receiver, flash apparatus, dummy or temperature pendulum, etc., sidereal break-circuit clironometers Negus 1833 and 1824, thennometers, air pump, dry cells, and, for use in time observations, a light observatory tent (a ridge-pole tent specially designed for the purpose and weighing only G 5 pounds), small meridian telescope aperture, 62111111; ~liagnifying power, 5O), light Saeg(for either time or latitbde, focal length, GCm; muller chronograph (weight about 50 pounds), and other accessories. Special attention mas paid to portability, and considerable reductions in weight were secured in the time outfit, and important gain in oconomy and labor. The entire apparatus, packed for shipment, weighed about 500 pounds (318 kilogrammes). The half-second pendnlum apparatus of tlie Survey has been fi~lly described and illustrated in United States Coast and Geodetic Survey Report for 1801, Appendix 16, since which time, however, i t has been.somewhat modified. A reversal of the usual relation of knife-edge and plane was made by Dr. Mendenhall, with the idea of obtaining greater invariability in the pendulum itself (see paper "On the use of lanes and knife-edges in pendulums for gravity measurements," American Journal of Science, XLV, page 144). Each of the new pendulums, A 4, A 5, and A 6, carries an agate plane in its head and swings upon an agate knife-edge which is inserted in a heavy brass plate resting on tho shelf in tlie receiver. The upper part of tho stem of the pendulum (fig. G A ) is forked, so that it passes beyond each end of the knife-edge, thus permitting both edge and plane to be sillgle pieces of agate. Experience proved that the dividing of tlie agate knife-edge or plane is objectionable as offering an o~portunity for the separated parts to be twisted out of the same plane by any strain in the surrounding metal. The plate in which tho knife-edge is embedded is not screwed rigidly to the shelf in the receiver, as formerly, but rests on three rounded steel projections in t l ~ i s fillelf, to which the plntc is fitted, and is held firmly ill place with a light screw. The agate lrnife-edge is formed by planes meeting a t an angle of 1300, and has a total bearing lehgtli of 19"In, being cut away in the center. A scale has been placed in the e ~ e end of tlle observing telescope, so that by holding tlie slit open and noting the rnovement of the image reflected by the pendulum mirror across the scale tho arc of oscillation may bo read directly'in mi~iutes as long as the arc is not large. Appliances have been provided for measuring statically the flexure of the support. A glass scale is mounted vertically above tlie knife-edge, adjiistable so that i t may be placed a t digerent lieiglits. With a weight, cord, pulley, and aluminum arm (to carry the tension over the edge of the receiver) a horizontal force in the plane of oscillation of tlle pendulum is applied directly behilid tlie knife-edge. By means of a, simple microscope, supported independently of the pier csrrying the receiver, magnifying 160 diameters, and provided with an eycpiece scale witli lines ha\ling an equivalent distance of 10 microns, the displacements of the scale above the knife-edge when tlie tension is'applied by su~pending the weight are noted to the nearest micron. The scale may be ohserved a t two or more heights above the knife-edge, and thus the movemelit a t tho edge estimated. The outside manometer and barometer, both troiiblesome additions, have been dispensed mitl~, consequent upon the adoption of lorn pressures. The air pressure is now obtained by a small manolneter set, in tlie pe~ldulumcase. This manometer was always transported in ,z vertical position so as to prevent air working into the closcd end. The Qametube was used throughout, and it was tested before and after tho ficld work and found corre6t. The same thermometer, Green GG04, mas used on the dummy pendulum a t all stations. I t s correctiolls as determilied by the Officeof Weiglits and Measures were applied to all readings. As a check, readings were also talren of another thermo~neterhanging in the air in the pendulum case. This thermometer invariably indicated the change of temperature, reading higher than the dummy thermo~neterml~elithe terriperature was rising, and lower when fi~llil~g. The new air pump for exliausti~lg the receiver weighs only about G pounds (2.7 kilogmn~mes). It is provided with a very ingenious self-packing piston, the invention of Mr. Fischer, Chief Mechanician. This piston, which is shown in fig. 1 by a section of a portion of the pump, is a 1e:itller cylinder stretched over a metal frame, with the liollow inside open to the outer air t h o u g h thc tnbulsr piston rod and handle. As soon as tlie air is partially exhausted from the pump

cylinder, which lias escape valves a t ~ W I Jend, the atmospheric pressure on the inside of the pistoll makes a perfect elastic packiug with lnir~imurufriction. The hollow Piston rod also fiirliislles a rcady means of lubrication,

U1 Flo. 1.-Sootion of portiou of air pump, ehowlng piaton. (Loathor indicated by n u h d blnck.)

Determination o f coeBcient8.-The effects on tho period of the pellduluni of changes of temperature and atmospheric density, and of various degrees of fioxihility of support, mere detormh~ed experimentally in January and ApriI, 1894. For this purpose penciulum B 4 was used as s standard to elimil~ete the rate of the chronometer, being smuug in an adjoiniug room under uniform conditions, while A 4, A 5, and A G mere successively swung under the various coliclitions desired to be chronometer investigated. Sinlultancous swings were made with the pendulums, using t,hc sall~e to operate both flash appa.ratuses by means of suitable electrical connectiollu. Tlie true period of B 4 being known, the diflorence from this of the observed period must be duo to rate of chronometer, which may therefore bo computed for each swing, and the resulting rate correction applied to the observations with A. This elegant comparative method of determining pendulum ooefflcients was first used by Airy and has more recently been employed by Von Storneck. Tho following is a summary of the reaults:

AS in the manner of making and reducing thege observations the pressure correction i s always a small quantity, no appreciable error can arise from treating i t as varying directly with the pressure. Flexure coeficient.-The eflect on the period of the pendulum of various degrees of flexibility of support was ascertained by determining the period under the different conditions (correcting for rate in the same manner as with the other coeficients), and measuring the flexure of the case and support statically with the'appliances already mentioned, all the observations being made with pendulum A 4. The amount of flexure encountered in actual work will in general be so small as to render ra slight uncertainty in this coefficierit i~lal)prcciable. A t the twenty-six stations where masonry supports were used i t ranged from 0.5 microns to 8.0 microns, with weight of 1.5 kilogrammes. A t a single station where it \\-as tiecessary to use wooden support it was as high as 18 microns. Method o f observation.-Several modifications were made by tho writer in the method of using in tliis work, resulting, i t is believed, in diminislled labor of observilig the half-second pondulu~ns as well as increased accuracy. These changes, solno of mhicli are applications for tlle first timeto sliort 1)eudulumsof lnethods which have been already used with long pendulums arid less portable apparatus, ]nay be summarized as follows: First, use of low air pressures (GOmm); second, long swings (eight hours) ; third, consecutive swings coveriug entire interval between timo observations and a t least forty-eight llours; fourth, use of two chronometers; fifth, sn~all initial arcs of oscillation (65') j sixth, observing coincidences by contacts of images; seventh, rneasurenlent of flexure of stand and support a t all ~tations. The general plan adoptod * was to swing the pendulums continuously a t each lace for two

i5n.e in hours.
days, or longer if necessary, so as to begill and end with star observatio~lsfor timo. I n case of unfavorable weather tho swings mere contirlued until tiiiie was obtained. The pendulums were (Coast and Geodctic Survey Office) before aud after each trip, and the swung a t ~ a s l l i n g t o n results ore treated relatively. One smiug (eight hours in length) mas mnde with each of tho three pendulums ill each position, reversed and direct, making in all six swings a t s station, except in the cnso of unfavorable weather. With tlle improved portable air pump i t was found possible to cxliaust the air from tho receiver to loss than one-tenth of an atmosphere in a few miuutes. It was tllereforo decided to adopt a sta,nda,rd pressure of G O ~ l l ~ill ~ l which to swing the pendulums, and also to langthen the swings to eight hours, which could be dorm with ease a t this low pressure. This improvoloent, besides lessoning tlie labor of observing, obviating t.ho necessity for much night work, and avoiding disturbances of t.he tomperaturo conditions consequent on frequent observations and changes of tho pendulum, further. made it possible to dispenso with barometer
. -

"At tho fir& three ~tatiou8, Cambridge, Boston, l ~ n d Ithaca, tho method of observation ditiered eomewhat from ~ the observsthat deecribod; tho old staudard pressure of 500mn1was used, tho swings were eech four hours l o n and tious with oach pendl~lurn covered twouty-Sour hour8. Tho results are strictly comparable, ho~vever, as the preceding and following obsorvntioue at Washington were made in the same manner ae at the Aold etatione in ouch case.

UNITED STATES COAST AND GEODETIC SUltVEY. and ontside manometer on the receiver. The diagram (fig.2) shows the decrement of arc of a half-second pendulum, both observed and computed on the law of diminution in geometrical ratio, a t two pressures, 509111m and 33mn1, and indicates that if desired, co~itinuous swings could be ruadc a t low pressures, of any length up to twenty-four hours. On accouht of its obvious advalitages a small initial arc of oscillation, about 56' total, was adopted, from which the arc diminishes in an eight-hour swing to about 201. A modification in the method of observing coincidences was liecessary for these small arcs, to explain which some description of the use of the coincidence apparatus must be given. In this apparatus a chronometer breaking an electric circuit every second is connected with an electro-magnet carrying on the end of its extended armature two shutters so arranged that a flash of light is thrown through a slit every time tho circuit is broken, and only then. (See illustration NO.20, Appendix 15, Iteport 1891.) This bright slit is seen in the observing telescope as reflected from two mirrors placed side by side, one stationary on the shelf in the receiver and the other carried by tho swinging pendulum. These ~nirrors are so :~djusted that when the penduluni is hauguig freely a t rest tho two images mill be seen in the same horizontal line in the telescope. The11the pendulum is swinging tlie image as reflected from the pendulum mirror will change its position as seen each second in the field of the telescope, because of the fact that the penduluni maltes a double oscillatiori in a little more than a second, and hence will be foulid lightly behinq its forper positioi~a t the end of each second wlien the flash is thrown. The moving image will thercfore appcar to travel up and dowri across the field of the tolcscope by successive? jumps, and coincidences are observed by noting the time when the two images are ill the same liorizontal line. It is evident that in the interval between two such plienomena tho pendulun~11asmade one less than twice as many oscillations as the chroriomcter has beat seconds, and that in an interval of time between the first and last of a nulnbcr of coincidences the number of oscillatior~s of the pendulum will be twice the number of seconds less the number of coincidence intervals. But when small arcs of oscillation are used, the rnotior~ of the moving image across tho field is slow, and the two images may overlap for a number of seconds. The modification introduced in observing is to note the contacts, or the time when these images touch aritl when tliey separate, and take the mean as tlie time of coincidence. By this means coincidences may be observed when tho total arc of oscillation is as small as st,witli an u~icertaiuty of iiot more than out or two seconds, which is far within the requirements for long swings. Only sufficient coincidences (usually three) were observed a t each end of the swing to make sure that the total number occurring iu the interval could be correctly estimated. The period was computed by combining the difference between the first aiid last "down" coincidences and the first and last "upv coincidences, thus eliminating all error due to imperfection of relative adjustment of the mirrors or possible change in this adjustment during the swing. Two chronometers mere used, coincidences boing noted alternately with each. This may be done very readily with this flash apparatus and a suitable arrangement for switching eitlier chronometer into circuit, and while increasing very little the labor of observing, affords an excellent check on the periods as well as a guard against accident to timepiece. I t is believed that by swinging tlie pendulums contiriuously between time observations the effect of diurn:~lirregnlarities of rate is entirely eliminated, as i t mill not be by any other method, slid this is strikingly shown by comparing the mean periods of the three peildulums as derived separately from the two chronometers (see Table G). The average difference a t the various stations is about -000 0001 second, and the maximum a t any station -000 0004 second, although the results for single swings often diff'er materially, in one case as much as .000 0027 second (in a four-hour swing on March 9, swing No. 17, Table G ) , c;orrespondiug to a reIative variation of daily rate of half a second. The use of a 50-ohm relay in the chronometer circuit rendered i t more constant, aiid protected the chronometer from the stronger currents necessary to work the flash apparatus. The two chronometers were compared on a chronogra1)h before and after time observations, (luring which, of course, only one mas used. They were kept uildcr as favorable conditions as possible regarding temperature, being in double leather cases, which were only opened once daily to wind. They were not moved during observations, as their breaks mere carried to the chronograph in the observatory and to the flash apparatus by wire, and a sidereal watch was used as a hack both in

REPORT FOR 1 8 9 P P A R T 1 1 . time observatione and in noting coincidences. The seconds of the watch were frequently compared with the chronometers by ear through the fact that the latter omit to break the circuit tat the sixtieth second. The average time required for a station, including traveling and all delays of every sort, was fiye and a half days. In the transcontinental series of stations remarkably favorable weather conditions were experienced, only two days being lost on account of inability to obtain star observations, out of a total of one hundred and five days and twenty stations. The usual program followed in the observations was: First day, station prepared and instruments set up, star observations for time between 9 and 10 p. m., pendulum A 4 (reversed) started a t 10 p. m.; second day, A 4 (direct) started at 6 a. m., A 6 (reversed) a t 2 p. m., time observations at 9 p. m., A 6 (direct) started a t 10 p. m. ; third day, A 6 (reversed) started a t 6 a. m., A 6 (direct) at 2 p. m., time observations a t 9 p. m., pendulum topped immediately afterwards; fourth day, instruments packed. Sf star observations were not obtained on the third night; the swings were continued, repeating the above order. Usually about forty-five minutes were required for each time determination, and the same for each set of pendulum observations, including the d n d coincidences of one swing, the changing of the pendulum and exhausting the receiver, and the f i s t coincidences of the next swing. Besides the above, latitude observations were made on one or two nights a t each place where neceeeary, the statiou was connected as to elevation with some known point, and the time and pen-. dulum computations were kept up from day Go day. A t two places, Colorado Springs and Terre! Haute, meridian lines were laid out by request. A t one station, Norris, Wyo., where only one! day could be spent, the regular program was necessarily shortened, and each pendulum mtw swung in one position only. For this reason, and on account of the unsatisfactory mounting of the receiver, fhis result is less reliable than the others. A t stations where the range of temperature was considerable, due to inability to secure a favorable location in this respect, thermometer wadil~gs were taken more frequently, and each was weighted according to the interval of time intervening. A t only four stations, however, did the total range of temperature in tho pendulum I receiver exceed 40 0. Rating o f chronometers.-At most of the stations transit observations of about eight stars were made by the writer each favorable evening to determine the daily rate of the chronometers. These were recorded chronographically, as also were the comparisons between the chronometers. The meridian telescope mas generally mointed on three wooden posts, set in the ground and well braced, though iu a few cases masonry piere yere built or found available. A t Princeton, Denver, and St. Louis the use of fixed observatory instruments was courteously granted, irnd at Cambridge, Charlottesville,and Oincinnati the time observations wore made by theobservatory authorities and the rates kindly furnished. At Denver the observations were made by Mr. Mendenhall. The precautions taken with the chronometers have already been mentioned. The following table (B) gives a summary of the rates on sidereal time. After each station are given the average h m perature and the elevation, as having an important influence on the rate. Ohronometer 1828 was not used after the first two stations on account of the remarkable change in its rate. A t Chmlottesville and Princeton, where time observations were ~lluch interrupted by unfavorable weather, the daily chronometer rates were derived by comparison with the staxldmd observatory olocke, the rate of the latter being assumed uniform between time observations. 8. The regular swings with all three pendulums were made on A I a t all stations with one accidental exception (Kansas City), but in order to guard against injury to it, and also to ascertain if there w a s any wear sufficient to affect the period, the second edg'e, A 1 1 ,was carried along and a colnpleta series of swings made on it a t Washington before and after the transcontinental series, as well as a t two stations, Chicago and Denver. The above mealis indicate a very satisfactory perma,iioucyof period. As these dchr~iiiiiations are distributed over different portiolis of the year, they niay also bo.talren :IS evide~ice witl~in the error of observation as to the invariability of gravity. As tlio toniperature a t which the observations were mado was did'ereut a t tliese various seasons, tlicy further confirm tho reliability of the temperature coeillcient, though of course some of these elc~l~erits nl;iy col~~pensate esoli other. It is possible that the change of period wliioh has bceu found in lualiy series of observ:~tionson redeterlnir~irigtlie period a t :t base station after a gravity expedition is duo to t l ~ e fact that tlie knife-edge was oftell used immeciiately after grindiiig. Thero are possibly slight irregularities in a new edge, and there may be soirie cliange of period until i t becolnes slightly worn. The fact that the knife-edge is not in tho 1)endulum will probably not diminish its effect on tho period in this respect. The knife-edges A I and A I1 h:~d botli liad considerable use previous to this work. set of swings on tlie standard edge added As the system used of nialcing a11 eritirely i~~depel~clent considerably to the timu : ~ u d labor ool~snlucd,tho pIi111 of using s u c ~ e s ~ i v et\vo l y or tliree knifeotlges in tlio regular set of observ;ttiol~s will l)rol,a\)ly be prcferablo. This mill give a constant

check on their permanency, will make the results with the separate pendulums more independent, and thus avoid the objection to swii~ging three pendulums on a single edge without increasing the time consumed. Resztlt8.-In Table G are given the details of the observations and reductions for each swing in the regular series, the details of the extra observations on knife-edge A 1 1 , and with the quarter-second pendulum8 being omitted. I n Table 0 are collected the mean periods for each pendulum and station, all reduced to the standard conditions, arc infinitely small, temperature 160 C., prexsure 60mm a t 00 C., sidereal time, and inflexible support. For this purpose the quantity -000 03608 (found by experiment) was subtracted from the periods'up to April 2, to reduce from S O O m mt o 60LLlm, as up to that date a standard pressure of 600mm was used, as already stated. The differences of the period of each pendulum from the mean of the three are also given as a test of the work. If the observations were perfect and the pendulums invariable these differences should of course be constant. A s will be seen, the variations of the differences are inconsiderable.

Although an elaborate measurement of the absolute force of gravity mas made a t Waehington in October, 1893, by Commandant Defforges,* i t is thought best to adhere for the present to the provisional value previously adopted for Washington (Smithsonian Institution), giving the above valuo a t Coast aud Geodetic Survey Office, so as to make these results directly comparable with those already published. Large discrepancies appear among the results of the best determinations of absoluto gravity made a,t tho base stations in Europe, as will be seen by examining the table of values reduced to Washington iu P a r t I V of this report. The mean of the twenty-nine results there given is not very different from the adopted provisional value. Reduotion to sea level.-The reduction known as Bouguer's formula (sometimes improperly called Young's rule) has been very generally applied in reducing pendulum observations to the level of

the sea. This formula is dg = + 7 1 - -

6

"""(

43z),

whero dg is the correction to observed gravity,

g is gravity a t sea level, H is elevation above sea level, r is radius of the earth, 6 is density of
* See P e r t V o f thie report. For deecription o f t h e apparatus e n d elegant methode developed e n d ueed by Commandant Defforges s e e MBmorial d u D4pOt G6n6rel d e la Guerre, Tome XV, Obaervatione d n Pendule, Parie, 1894; also Procee-Verbeux d u ComiM International doe Poide ot M o ~ u r e s pour 1891, Meeure d e l'Inteneit6 abeolne d e le Peeanteur B Breteuil; e n d verioua papers in C o ~ ~ ~ p R to Ol I ~I I ~ do IIH l'bsooietion G4od6eique Internetionale, D o m 1887 t o 1893.

22

UNITED STATES COAST AND GEODETIC SURVEY.

matter lying above sea level, and n is mean density of the earth. The first term takes account
of the distance from the earth'a center, and the second term of tlie vertical attraction of the

matter lying between the sea level and station, on the supposition that the latter is located on an indefinitely extended horizontal plain. Wherever the topography about a station departs tnaterially from this condition of a horizontal plain a third term must be added to tlie above formula, b a n g a correction to the second term or to observed gravity on accoulit of such irregularities." This, which may be called the topographical correction, will always be positive, as the effect of all deviations from the horizontal plain, whether hills or mountains risixig above the station, or valleys or canyons lying below it, will be to diminish the force of gravity. It is evident that an elevation of any sort exactly neutralizes the vertical attraction of a similar but inverted mass below the station level, so that the removal of both would not change the force of gravity a t the station. This correction may be readily computed for any point where contour maps of the surrounding country are.available, by describing thereon concentric circles about the station and drawing radial lines therefrom a t equal angular distances, as show~l in figure 3 (or this design may be drawn on a sheet of tracing paper to be laid over the map).

The space included between two circles may be designated a.s a zone, and the part of a zone between two radii as a compartment. The vertical attraction of a cylinder of radius a, height h, and density S on a point a t one extremity of its axis will be 2 ~ (a 6 + h - .\/-I. As a ; zone is the difference between two cylinders, say of radii a and at, its vertical attraction will be 2x6 (a - a' - .\/aZ+ kz d v I E 2 ) . Tho attraction a t its surface of the earth considered as a sphere is 3 z A r where n is the mean density arid r the radius of the earth. Therefore the effect

sutliciently acourate except when the topography is very uneven near the station, in which case the preceding formula must be used. 1~ is to be taken for each compartlnent as the diEerence in elevation, regardless of sign, between the station and tho average surface of tilo compartment. As this will vary for differant portions of a zone, the parts of the formula irlvolving h must be computed separately for each compartment therein, and the mean applied iu the formula for the zone. When these zones have been carried to such a, distance from a station that their effect begins to become insignificant, the vertical attraction of the remaining region may be readily computed by the formula dg = lc ( *1Z2+-h2 a), where a is the outer radius of the last zone, this being the formula for the difference between an infinite plain of thickness 1~ and a cylinder of height 1~ and radius a.. The : m a immediately about the station within the first circle may often be neglected as ;bpproximately level, or otherwise the effect of its irregularity rnay be computed by taking the difference between a cylinder and a cone, the formula becoming a2 where a is the radius and h the difference of elevation a t distance n from

the station, taken for each compartlnent separately, keeping in mind always that we are computing only the correction t o the vertical attraction of a n infinite horizontal plain through the station, and thereforo only need take account of deviations therefrom. The total correction for a station mill of course bo the surn of tho corrections for the separate zones. Where tho station is a t the summit of a small hill rising out of a comparatively level country, i t will generally suffice to troat the hill as a cone without dividing the country into compartments; the formula for this case is h2 dg = 76 --- which represents the difference between the vertical attraction of an infinite plain daZ+ ha' of thickness h aud a cone of height h and radius a. The egect of topographical irregularities has been investigated in the manner described for all tho stations of tho past season, using wherever available tho contour maps of the Geological Survey. Although applied in all cases where appreciable, a t only one station, Pikes Poak, was this correction found to be of rea,l importance. This is partly due to tlie favorable location of the stations, but also to the fact that except on the summit of rugged mountains or very close to tlieir base, or in deep, narrow valleys, this correction must necelssarily be small. The effect of placing an infiuite horizontal plain 114 feet (35metres) in tliickness, or a sphere 338 feet (103 metres) in tliaineter, and of deusity equal to one-half tlie mean density of the earth, immediately above a stiltion mould be to diminish gravity by only 404 dy~le, or about the d o T 0 t h pa.rt, wllich niay a t present be taken as the utmost limit of probable accuracy of observation. These considerations iridicats that for a majority of stations in ope11 country a rough estimate will show that tho topographical correction is inappreciable. The question of the proper reduction of pendulum observations to the level of the sea, involving as i t does the various theories of the condition of the earth's crust, and affecting very materially the use of such observations in deducing the figure of the earth, is a most important one, and has led to the exl,ression of many different opinions. Bouguer's reduction, above described, hue been very generally adopted. Professor Eelmert, in the masterly discussion of pendulum observatiot~sin his Hiihere CeodHsie, develops and uses the condensation method, assuluing a surface 21 ltiloiiletres below the sea level, to which all the overlying material is condensed. As approsimately applied by him in the discussion of coutine~ltal stutio~is this rcductiol~ amounts t o omittlng t l ~ o correction for attraction (second term) ill Uouguer's formula, but not so in coast and oceallic isl:~nd stations, where the effect of the lesser density of sea water is taken into account.

24

UNITED STATE8 COAST AND GEODETIC SUBVEY.

M. Faye, 'in papers published in Comptea Rendus in 1880 and 1883, advocates that the continental attraction term in Bouguer's formula be omitted, but that all local deviations of the elevation of the station from the general level of the land surface or sea bottom be allowed for, as, for instance, the attraction of a mountain on a station a t its summit, or of an isolated island. This subject has also been discussed by Stokes, Peirce, Ferrel, and many others. In the recent reports on pendulum observations in the Proceedings of the International Geodetic Association, tho reductions have been made by two methods: First, with Bouguer'e formula, and second, using the reduction for elevation, omitting the attraction term; and the same plan is followed in tho summary of results given in Table E. The surface densities here given have been kindly furnished by Mr. G. K. Gilbert, of tho United States Geological Survey, who visited personally many of the stations and made careful estimates for all.* They represent tlie average for tho mass above sea level at each station. The value 5-58 has been used for tho mean density of the earth. So a s to be able to study the results moro intelligently, tho values a t sea level have been co~npared with those computed by an assumed theoretical forrnultl g = 078.066 (1+ ,006 243 sin"), which is based on Clairant7stheorem, Olarke's figure of the earth, and the assumption that gravity is normal on the eastern coast of the United States. Finally, this table gives the differences observed, minus computed gravity, for both methods of reduction t o sea level. Thess differences are shown graphically in the diagrams in connection with the map (fig. 4), whore also aro included two stations, San Francisco and Mount Hamilton, previously determined. While i t is somewhat unsafe to draw general conclusions from a single series of observations, yet the favorable and systematic situation of these stations with respect to an unusual variety of continental conditions perhaps warrants the pointing out of a few possibleinferences. With Bougaer's reduction there is apparently a considerable defect of gravity under the western mountains and plateaus having a striking relation in amount to the average continental clevations. This can not bo accounted'for to any great exterit by a supposed abuormal condition in the mass above sea level, as it would require that that mass should have a density of zero to offset this defect; the presumption is, therefore, that there is a deficiency of density below sea level which in general compensates the elevated masses. Oontrary to a recent assertion, the residuals do not appear to have .-- -* Mt. Gilbert also furnished the following ellumeration of the more important underlying rocks, stated ln the
.-up-

order of their relative thicknws, for each of the gravity stations except Boston, Cambridge, and Philadelphia: Princeton, Shale, sandstone. Sand, clay. Washington ( C o a t and Geodetic Survey), Waehington (Smithsonian), Sand, clay. Ithace, Shnle. Charlottesville, Gneise. Deor Pnrk, Sand, shale. Cleveland, Shale. Cincinnati, Shnlo, limostone. 25

any relation to distance from the sea, or to the elevation of the particular point of observation, as is shown by the fairly horizontal lines under that part of tho central plain (Cincinnati to Ellsworth) where the altitude is nearly the same, and the nearly equal deficiencies found a t stations which, like Guriuisou, Pikes Peak, Colorado Spriiigs, and Denver, vary enormously in elevation. With the reduction fbr elevation only the apparerit defect of gravity largely disappears, as sl~own by tho nearly horizontal line of residuals undor the great central plains, where the altitude varies from 151 to 1841 metros (495to 6041 feet), and by the average result in the mountain rogioiis. I11 tlle latter, however, the line shows considerable departures from the normal, both positive arid negative, the residuals showing a striking relation to the elevations of the stations as compared with the elevations of the surrounding country. Pikes Peak, Pleasant Valley, Mount Hamilton, and the Yellowstoue statiou are above the average level and show an excess of gravity, while the remaining Rocky Mountain stations are below the general levol and all show a defect of gravity. This condition is especially marked in the c:tse of Green River and Grand Junction, in the bottom of great eroded valleys, aud Pikes Peak station, on the summit of an isolated mountain. The residuals are not proportional to the elevation of tho station itself abovo sea level, as is a t once seen by comparing Mount Hamilton, Salt Lako, Grecn River, Grand Junction, and Denver, which are of nearly equal elevation. Finally, with oitller systoln of reduction tho residuals point to the probability tha8 gravity is large on the seacoast as compared with the interior. Whether this can have ally connectioli with the effects of erosion and deposition of continental mattor is a question upon which the observations in this series are far too limited to throw any clear light, but for investigating which certain portio~ls of the United States would furnish an excellent field. The results of this series mould therefore seem to lead to the conclusion that goneral continental elevations are colnpensatod by a deficiency of density in the matter below sea level, possibly in much the same way that the portion of an iceberg standing above sea lovol is compeilseted by the differeilce in density of ice and water belolv the surface, but that local topographical irrogularities, whether elevations or depressions, are not cornponsated for, such irregularities being mair~tainccl by the partial rigidity of the earth's crust. Tlie residuals with Bouguer's reduction should then be interpretad as a measure of tlie deficiency of density, and, on tho other hand, the residuals with the reduction for elevation should be takon as a measure of the lack of compensation, after allowing for uncertainties of observation and the effects of local geological conditions. Developing the idea of M. Faye, observed values of g may be corrected for this lack of compensation by adding or subtracting the vertical attraction of a horizontal plain whose thickness is the difference in elevation between the station and the This correction may be expressod drJ = 2 g - which reprer 4 n senta the attraction of an indefinitely extended horizontal plain of thickness 1, and density 8, and the correction is positive for stations below the average level and negative for tliose above. This method has been tested by applying i t to the stations most affected in the present series, the average elevation beirig approximately estimated from a contour map for tlie country within an arbitrarily adopted radius of 100 miles of each station. The resulting corrections aro shown in the following table, together with the residuals, g observed minus g computed (under the head of Faye's roductionn), when this compensation correction was applied, together with the elevation and topographical corrections. These residuals are also compared with those obtained by the two methods of reduction in Table 0. The sums of the residuals (regardless of sign) for the fourteen stations areaverage surrounding surface.
With reduction by Bouguer's method '677 dynes. 11 " for elevation 0.677 " 11 by Faye's method 0 .I76

indicating apparently a considerable advantage for the latter. It is probable that no particular significance attaches to tliese residuals remaining after the application of Faye's reduction, for several reasons; other values would certainly result if 8 different area were considered in estimating the average surroundirig elevation, or if weight were given according to proximity to the station in making this estimation; and the average elevatio~ishere given are subject to some uncertainty, as they were obtained from a smit11 8c::llu III:L~).

An inspection of the table shows that the residuals with Bougnor's reduction are very nearly proportional t o the average surrounding elevations, though bearing no relation to the actual etation elevations. The true reduction of gravity observations to sea level mould appear to be one that would take account not only of the attraction of matter above the sea level but also of the general differences of density below, as well as of the local lack of co~npensation if the latter can be proved to have a systornatic relation to the topographical situation of the point of observation, as is strongly indicated by these results. With such a method i t is quite possible that the so-called anomalies of gravity will largely disappear and that the distribution of gravity on the earth's surface will be found to follow Clairaut's law sufficiently closely to greatly enhance the value of pendulum observations in relation to the problem of the earth's figure. As furnishing further evidence on this subject, there is collected in Table P :t Rummary of the various other Coast and Geodetic Survey series of gravity measurements baaed on WashingMr. Preston, and Mr. Smith. A s these include a number of ton, and made by Dr. Meiidenl~all, oceanic island and coast stations, it was riecessary in applying Faye's idea of reduction to take between sea water and land. This was done by assuming the account of the difference in deri~ity water as condensed down until i t s density equaled that of land, and using the ul)per surface of this condensed mass in e~timating the average elevation of the surrounding region. I n application, the depth of sea water a t any point, multiplied by (1

- $1,where 6, is density of sea water

and 6 is density of land beneath the station, gives the depression below sea level of the assumed surface. By tekirig these depressions as negative elevations, the average surrounding elevatioll may be conveniently estimated for all stations, whether on large or small islands or continental coasts, the principal difficulty being tbe lack of sufficient data as to ocean depths, and of contour maps, and the uncertair~ty as to how large an area should be considered for each station. A similar treatment could bc applied to continental stations where tho regions surrounding varied the average olevations considerably in density. I11 Table F are given the elevations of the statio~ls, within a radius of 100 miles, considering the mater as condensed (estimated in nearly all cases from very imperfect data), the observed valueu of g r a ~ i t ~and y , the residuals, observed g minus computed g for both Bouguer's and Faye's reduction to sea level. These reductions were applied

Mean deneity of the earth from Pikes Peak pendulum observatw?~.-A value for the mean density of the earth has been deduced from the gravity measurements made on the summit of the Peak arid at Colorado Springs, near the base. This method of comparing the known mass of a mountain with the uuknown mass of the earth has been used on a t least four previous occasions, but not, it is believed, uuder as favorable conditions as the present, for in this case contour maps of the Pealr and surrounding country were available, and the monntrtin itself was found to be composed of rock of an unusually uniform de~iuit~y. Mr. Whitman Cross, of the United States Geological Survey, who haa studied the geology of the vicinity, kindly furnished data in regard

30

UNITED STATES COAST AND GEODETIC SURVEY.

to the specific gravity of the rock of which the Peak is composed. Twelvo specimens collected from various parts and determined under Nr. Gilbert's direction gave values as follows: 3-57,2.60, 2.61, 2.61, 2.62, 2.67, 2.67, 2.58, 2.61, 2.61, 2.63, 2.71. The mean, 2.615, has been'adopted. The difference in gravity a t the base and summit of a mountain will be, by Bouguer's formula,

considering the upper station as on an infinite horizontal plain, tho lower station as unaffected by the attraction of the mountain, and neglecting the insignificant effect of change in centrifugal force. Here H i s the difference in elevation of the two stations (2452 meters), r is the radius of the earth, 6 is the density of the mourltain (2.615)' and A is the mean density of the earth. The correction to observed gravity for local topographical irregularities (or departure from the condition of a horizontal plain) was carefully computed for these two stations as described in discussing the g * 439, and for Colorado Springs reduction to the sea level, and found to be for Pikes Peak + -3 2rA 38 8 27 (using the metre as unit of length). he' observed values of gravity mere for Pikes 2r n Peak 978.940, and for Colorado Springs 979.476, to which must be applied tho above correctious for topographical irregularities to obtain dg for the above formula, which then becomes:

+-

which reduces to 636 = 2-g
T

or A = 2.153 6 = G63.

The value for the mean density of the earth derived from the Pikcs Peak observations is therefore 5.63. I n this computation no account has been taken of the estimated difference in density below t h e level of Colorado Springs.

Mention of this work and its objects has alreacly been made (lteport 1891, Part 1 1 , p. 56.3): A room havirlg been Atted up for pendulurn worlc in the basernont of the Coast and Geodetic Survey a t tho Smithsoniari InstiOffice, ib was desired to compare this station wit11 the former base statioi~ tation, so that relative gravity observ:lt,iol~s referred to either poiiit as a base could be reduced to a comm6nsystem. For t,his ~ ) u r ~ ) othe s e telegraphic method was c?mployed, which consists in the siruultal~eousswingiug of two pentlulums a t stations connected by wire, so that the same timepiece ]nay be used a t both, thus f'reei~~g the observations from tlie rate of the chronometer, and are thexi interchanged between avoidil~gtho necessity for tirne observatiolis. If tile ~)ulidulums the stations and tlie operation repe:rted, or if they arc: colnparcd a t tlic salne ])lace before or afterbe deduced. The telegrapliic method has been wards, the difference in the forco of gnb\-it,y ~rlay employed ill Europe,+ but is modified in the present iustauce by the alterllate use of a chrono~neter a t e;tch end of tho line, wit11 the oWect of thus elinliilatirig the eEect of any variation ill the trarislnissio~~ time tliat niight occllr during a. s\vilig.$ Descriptiotb o f rrtations.-At the CoList :~iidGeodetic Survey Ottice ot)servations were inade in the pendulum room already described. A t tlie 81nitliso1iiar1institution the pendulums were swung ill tlie room ill the northeast basement, which ]lad previol~slybeell useii for tliis purpose. The receiver was placed on the same brick pier 011 wllicli the lialf-secoud pendulums were swung in March, 1801. Thia station is about 1430 metres west and 180 metres north of the Coast and Geodetic Survey Office, and tlle elevation above 1ile:Ln sea level is 10 i~letres.

V.. -ANOMALIES IN THX FOROE OF GRAVITY ON THE OONTINENT OF NORTH AXEEIOA, BY OOMMANDANT DEFFORGES.

The studies of the force of gravity undertaken by the Service Wographique of the army have perluitted the formulation of some interesting empirical laws, which were submitted on July 15,1803, to the judgment of the Academy by the minister of war. It is &own by the recent measures, and by a certain number of older determinations which can be combined with certainty with the contemporary observations, that the shore of the same sea appears to possess a characteristic force of gravity, the variation of which dong that &ore follows suficiently exactly the law of the sine squared of the latitude announced by Olairant. But, on the one hand, the islands which arise from the great depths of the sea present a considerable excess of gravity, as has been inferred since the first discussions of observations with the pendulum made during the old voyages of circumnavigation; and, on the other hand, upon the continents of Europe, Africa, and Asia there is proved a defect of gravity which seems in the distribution of the masses of the terrestrial crust to counterbalance the excess of the islands of the ocean. It was of interest to extend and confirm this last law, and to ascertain if the American continent actually presented, like the other continents, this negative anomaly of gravity, and to wha* degree. Taking advantage of a voyage of duty to the United S b h s , I have been able, with the aid of funds generously placed at my disposition by the Academy, to execute with the ' L reversible inversablen pendulum relative observations of the force of gravity a t seven stations on the continent of North America. Furthermore, upon a courteous request addressed by Dr. T. 0. Mendenhall, Superintendent of the army, I of the Ooast and Geodetic Survoy, to the director of the L L Service G6ographique9? have measured the absolute force of gravity a t Washington with the pendulums of Bmnner. The relative stations have been chosen in euch a manner as to bring out MImuch as possible the continental anomalies. Two of the stations, Sau Francisco and Washington, are situated near the shores of tho oceans, and within a few degrees upon tho same parallel. A central station, a t Salt Lake City, not distant from the Great Salt Lake, occupies a point in the lowest part of tho great plateau between the Rocky Mountains and the Sierra Nevada. Another station a t the observatory recently founded at Denver, on the other side of the Rocky Mountrtins, at more than 1,600 metres elevation, is situated upon the vast plateau which serves as a pedestal t o the Rocky Mountains and descends by insensible degrees to the valley of the Mississippi. These two stations, Salt Lake Oity and Denver, are sufficientlydistant fronl tho most elevated mountain masses to escape the topographic attraction, and their situation upon the solid mass itself of the backbone of the American continent render them well suited to reveal the continental defect of gravity with its greatest value.. S. Ex. 8, pt. 2 4

50

UNITED STATES COAST AND GEODETIC SURVEY.

The other stations, Mount Hamilton, Chicago, and Montreal, situated on both'sides of the stations of the great plateau, serve for transition to the stations on the borders of the oceans, and permit the following of the variation of the anomaly, roferred to gravity observed a t Paris, until beyond its change of sign, which takes place at some distance from the ocean shore, following the law already established in Europe and Algeria. The absolute force of gravity, memured a t Washington in the pendulum room of the Coast snd Geodetic Survey Office, is g = 9.80 165 metres The relative measure gave, between Paris and Washington, g = 9.80 169 metres The accord of the two valuoe is entirely satisfactory. I have adoptsd for Washington the mean g = 9.80 167 metres The table which follows includes the values of g measured, relatively to Paris, a t the seve; American stations, and for each of these: First, the reduction to the level of the sea, following the formula of Bouguer; second, the theoretic gravity, calculated according to the law of Clairant and with the flathning of Clarke, considering as normal the force of gravity a t Paris j and finally, third, the anomaly of the observed gravity.

The curve (here omitted) gives a very clear idea of the general change of the anomaly of gravity on the American continent.* Although the deviations of the vertical have not yet been determined a t the American Stations, the largest values which experience has given for this deviation on the globe mould not affect the anomalies to a sensible amount. These results entirely confirm the facts of observation anuounced in the note of July 15 last. If is interesting to no& that the continental anomaly upon the high American plateau is very nearly equal and of opposite sign to the anomalies of the islands in the great depths of the Pacific and Atlantic.

A REPORT ON A GEOLOGIO EXAMINATION O F SOME COAST AND GEODETIO SURVEY GRAVITY STATIONS.

By G. K. GILBERT, Geologist United Statea Geologioel Survey.

DEPARTMENT O F THE INTERIOR, UNITED STATESGEOLOGICAL SURVEY, Washington, D. C., Marclb 19, 18.95. DEAR SIR: In accordance with an informal arrangement mado a year ago between this office and the Superinteudent of the C o a ~ Survey, t Mr. G. R.Gilbert was illstru~ted to make some special geological examinations in conjunction wit11 the work of Mr. Puttiam in the messure~nentof gravity. As this work on behalf of the Geological Survey was merely accessory to that of the Ooaat Survey, i t seelns proper that its results should be published by the Coast Survey ill co~ijunction with the report by its own ofEcer. I therefore transmit to you herewith Mr. Gilbert's report, which is in the form of a lettor addressed to yourself. Yours, with respect, OHAS.D. W A L O O ~Director. T, Gen. W. W. DUFFIELD, Superintendent United Statea Ooast and Geodetio Sur?)ey.

DEPARTBXENT O F THE INTERIOR, UNI~ED STATESGEOLOGICAL SURVEY, Washington, D. O.,Narck 19, 1895. SIR : About a year ago Dr. T. 0. Mendenhall, then Superintendent of the Coast and Geodetic Survey, invited me to make suggestion8 as to the selection of points for gravity stations. He was pt that time plauning a transcontinental chain of stations, approximately in latitude 390, and he desired to have the'points of observation so chosen aa to give light not only on geodetic problems but also on problems of peculiar interest to geologists. I n one of the conferences on this subject i t was suggested that special geologic examination of stations occupied was desirable, and as I was to be engaged in field work in Colorado while the gravity determinations were made, it was informally arranged that the precise points occupied by the observer should be communicated to me in Oolorado, and I should visit as many stations as practicable on my way back to Washington in the autumn. This arrangement was afterwards carried out, permission therefor being granted by the Director of the Geological Survey, and all Ilecessary information as to places, etc., being forwarded to me by Mr. G. R. l'utnam, the Assistant in charge of the work. T l ~ e stations visited by me were Colorado Springs, Denver, Wallace, Ellsworth, Kansas Oity, St. Louis, Terre Haute, Chicago, Cincinnati, and Cleveland. As the mean density of the earth is greater than the density of the visible crust, there must be a general increase of density downward. So far as zones of equal density are spheroidal shells parallel to the superficial spheroid of reference, the distribution of densities may be regarded as regular or normal. To whatever extent the different parts of a spheroidal shell vary in density
51

52

UNITED STATES OOAST AND GEODETIC SURVEY.

the distribution is irregular. The geodesist and the geologist alike are interested in the determination of tile nature and extent of such irregularities. With the outermost portion of the lithosphere the geologist 11as some acquaintauce, and lie knows that it is not of uniform density. He suspects that the zone of heterogeneity extends farther, characterizing all that indefinitely limited portion of the lithosphere which he calls crust, and lie hopes that with the n~ultiplication of pendulum stations much may be learned of the extent and distribution of crustal inequalities. If the heterogeneity indicated by the pendulum is confined to the zone which is subject to direct observation or clear inference by the geologist, or if i t resides chiefly ill that zone, then tlie application of a correction properly based on geologic observations should render the measurements of local gravity more harmonious, If the application of such a correction fails to diminish the discrepancies of gravity determinations, the chief cause of local variation would seem to lie farther beneath the surface, or a t least to range farther from the surfi~ce. A t each station visited 1 examined the for~nations visible a t the .surface, collected samples to be used afterwards for tlio determination of specific gravities, and compiled such data as mere available from wells and the labors of other geologists as to the character of underlying formations. The densities, or specific gravities, of the specimens collected were determined by Mr. George W. Stose, Assistant Geologist, United States Geological Survey. For this purpose blocks of the size known as hand specimens were employed wherever practicable, and care mas taken to obtain the specific gravity of the rock as saturated with water, except in the case of specimens representing formations which lay above water line. Determinations were also made of a considerable number of other specimens in order to obtain average values for the densities of such rocks as were reported in well records, but were not available for specific determination. A great region, including the stations visited, is characterized by sedimentary rocks lying in nearly horizontal beds. These are of such vertical extent that a t none of the stations have they been completely traversed by the drill; but it is legitimately inferred from a study of tbe relations of these rocks as exhibited elsewhere that they have a total thickness rauging from one-half mile to 3 miles, and that beneath them are crystalline rocks which are not similarly arranged in horizontal strata. but are disposed jn beds of less regular .shape whose boundaries are often highly inclined or vertical. The particular disposition and arrangement of these crystalline rocks in tho viciuity of any of the stations can not be inferred from data now in the possession of the geologist, so that they must be classed for the purposes of tliis discussion with the subcrust of unknown density. Nevertheless, as the sedi~uentarycolumns are of unequal height, their attraction can not be compared to advantage without making some assumption as to the density of the crystallines on whose uneven surface they stand. The particular assumption on mhich the computations and accompanyi~~g tables are baaed is that the average density of the crystallines is 2.70. An average density of 2-65 was also assumed, and the computations repeated, but the results were so nearly identical that they are omitted to avoid prolix repetition. The standard density, 2.70, was subtracted from the densities of the various sedimentary rocks detenilined, reported, or inferred to occur beneath each of the gravity stations, aud the differepces were employed in the subsequent computations. In Table I the stations are listed in the order of their longitudes from east to west. Tho thickness of the sedimentary rocks was in each cam partly determined by local well records and Partly of estimated by the aid of well records or surfme measurements a t other points. I n the Ellsworth and Wallace the wells are shallow, and the bases of inference were so slender that the estimates of thickness have small value. I n the computation of mean densities tho measured densities of individual formations were used so far as possible, and in the absence of direct measurernents limestones were estimated a t 2.70, shales a t 2.43, and sandstones a t 2-40. The densities ascribed to the rocks a t Wallace and Ellsworth are interpolations. The corrections to the local detcrrninatious of gravity (column 6 ) were computed by means of the fbrmula

where H represents the thickness of the sedimentary rocks, d tbeir mean density, A the earth's lneali density, and r the earth's radius. The quantities in column 7 are residuals derived from tliose in column 6 by subtracting the mean of the q~isntities in column G from the several quantities.

In consideri~igtho eEect of applying such geologic correctio~isas nppoar i11 column 6 of Tablo I to local observatiou of gravity two quite distiuct and opposing points of view should be kept in 11lind: (a) High rigidity.-Tho earth's crust may be regarded as rigid, or a t least stiff enough to support the continents by its stiffnoss. Ln this case no necessary relation esists between altitude and density of crust. On this theory every measurement of gravity on land should be con-ected by subtracting fkom it the attraction duo to the inatter lying between tho statiou and the surface of tho spheroid of reference. (6) Isostasy.-The earth's crust may be regardod as relatively weak aud plastic. I n this case the continental masses and ocoan betis are in qoasi-hydrostatic equilibrium, and altitude is inversely related to the density of tho crust beuesth. On this hypothesis the correction should not be applic?d. The method employed in discussing tlie eEect of the geologic corroctions mas (1) to make the determiuations as homogenoous as possible by applying ell corroctions excopt the geologic one, and then lloto the outstanding discordauoe as shown by the rosiduals, or differences betmeo~~ individual measures arid the mean of all the measures ; (2) to repeat the process, including the geologic corrections, and thus derivo a second series of residuals; und (3) compare tho two series of rosiduals. I n Table 1 1 , postulati~igthe theory of high rigidity, c o l u ~ n ~ 8i givos tho observed values of gravity after corroctiori for latitude, altitude, local topography, and the attractiou of matter above sea level. Tho adjust~ne~it for latitude consisted in reducing each value to its equiv:ilent a t latitude 400. The corrections for altitude atid for the dofect of attraction escribablo to the local topographic relief mere tlioso tabult~tedby Mr. Putuam. Tho correction for tho attractioxi of matter abovo sea lovol assumed tho density of that matter to be 2-70. It should be noted in this connection that the (positive) correction for dtitudo and the (negative) correction for the attraction of matter above sea level are both too s~nallunder the theory of high rigidity; for these corrections, as computed, are proportional to tho height of the stations abovo the gooid, whereas they should be proportional to the height of the stations above the spheroid of roforence; and the theory of co~itinents uphold by terrestrial rigidity irnplies that the geoid in continental aroas lies above tho spheroid of reference. It is probnblo that if due account were taken of this factor the divergence of tlio valuos in column 8 would bo so~uewhat reduced. The values of gravity in column 9 more obtained by adding to tlio values in coluniu 8 tho geologic corrections of column 6 (Table I). The discordauoes of tho values in co1ui1111s S and 9 are exhibited by the residuals in columns 10 and 11.

It appears from the footings of the table that the gravity determinations a t the ten stations, if compared under sthe hypothesis of rigidity (but without allowance for the deformation of the geoid), exhibit a diversity or discordance measnred by the mean of residuals, 0.064 dynes; and that the application of the geologic correction reduces the discordance to 0.054 dynes. If these memures of discordance be further compared with the measure of the diversity of the geologic corrections, 0.010 dynes (column 7, Table I),it appears that the geologic corrections have the maximum possible effect in the direction of harmony, for it is only through their own diversity that they affect the diversity of the quantities to which they are applied. If any general conclusion may be drawn from these data, it would Reem to be that correctio~ls for the densities of the local formations may advantageously be applied to gravity determination0 discussed under the hypothesis of terrestrial rigidity. Table 1 1 1is bmed on computations in which isostasy is postulated. The values of gravity in column 12 were corrected. as before for latitude, altitude, and local topography, but not for the attraction of matter between the surface and sea level. I n this case the correction for altitude needs little qualification for the deformation of the geoid. The values of gravity after the application of the geologic correction appear in column 13. The quantities in columns 14 and 16 are residuals from columns 12 and 13, respectively.

f i o m the footings of this table i t appears that the gravity detarminations a t the ten statiollo, if compared under the hypothesis of isostasy, exhibit a discordance measured by 0.009 dynes, and that the application of the geologic correction does not reduce the discordance.
