APPENDIX NO. 2-1894.

TELEGRAPHIC DETERMINATION OF THE FORCE OF GRAVITY AT BALTIMORE, MD., FROM SIMULTANEOUS PENDULUM OBSERVATIONS AT WASHINGTON AND BALTIMORE.

B y R. D. PRESTON, Assidant. Submittod for publicntio~iYobruary 15, 1805.

B l a n k page r e t a i n e d f o r p a g i n a t i o n

APPENDIX NO.2-1894.

TELEGRAPH10 DETERMINATION O F T E E FOROE O F GRAVITY A T BALTIMORE, MD., FROM SIMULTANEOUS PENDULUM OBSERVATIONS AT WASHINGTON AND BALTIMORE.
By E. D. PRRBTON, Assistnnt.
Submitted for publication February 15, 1895.

I n obedience to instructions of June 29,1893, a determination of the relative force of gravity between Washington, D. C., and Baltimore, Md., was undertaken. The exact points occupied were the Coast and Geodotic Survey Office in this city and the Johns Hopkins University a t Baltimore. Through tho kindness of President Gilman and Professor Romland the basement of the physical laboratory was placed a t our disposal. Tho height above mean tide is 100 feet (30.5 metres). A t Washington the pendulum was 45 feet (13.7 metres) above mean tide. The instruments used were the recently constructed half-second pendulums, and the method was that of swinging simultaneously two pendulums, the periods of both being determined by means of the same chronometer. The signals wero transmitted telegraphically. The distance from Washington to Baltimore is 40 miles. It is obvious that in the application of such a p l a ~ ii t is unnecessary to know the rate of the chronometer, and hence we may dispense with the star observations, a very laborious part of the usual scheme in the relative determinations of gravity. This method, tho first account of which appeared in the report of Dr. T. 0.Mendenhall on the transfer of our initial gravity station from the Smithsoninn Institution in this city to the Coast and Geodetic Survey Offlce, promises to be one of surprising accuracy. The work just referred to, executed by Mr. G. R. Putnam, Assistant, Coaut and Geodetic Survey, and Mr. Von der Trenck, Acting Aid, gave results in which the greatest discrepancy from the mean was only one part in two and rt half millions (Appendix No. 15, Report for 1891). The line, however, was short; but there is no rectson why the distance between the stations ehould enter a s a function of the accuracy, granting that the elmtrical oonnections, batteries, etc., remain the same from day to day. Por details regarding the execution of the present work reference may be made to Appendix No. 16, above cited. The eystem followed in the Washington-Bdtimore determinations was essentially the same and need not be retold. The use of two chronometers, one a t each station, eliminated from the result any error arising from the variation of the transmission tilno of the electric current during the experiment. The pendulums used were A,, A,, and A,, st one etation, and BI, BZ, and B, a t the other. 4 and B1 were swung simultaneously, as likewise were A, and B,, and finally 8, and B3. The B pendulums are of the old form, having the knife-edge on the pendulum and the plane on the support. The A pattern has the plane on the pendulum and the knife-edge on the support. After three days' work with B a t Washington and A a t Baltimore the pendulums and receivers were interchanged rtnd another set mas made with A at Washington and B a t Baltimore.
5!)

60

UNITED STATES COAST AND GEODETIC SURVEY.

Finally, the pendulums mere simultaneously swung a t Washington, A* being compared with Bl, A, with B,, and & with B , . The pendulums were swung in the prime vertical a t both stations. Sidereal chronometer Negus No. 1823 mas used a t Washington and No. 1824 a t Baltimore throughout the work. From these threesets,, that is, from the swir~gsbefore and after the iuterchauge, and from direct comparison at the same place, it is possible to deduce a value for the difference of the force of gravity between Washington and Balti~noreand also two values for the difference of the times of oscillation of the pendulums. A complete and syrnrnetrical scheme would necessitate another direct compariso~~ a t the second stmation (Baltimore),which would furnish another value for the difference of gravity also. Letting n t, = the difi'erence.of the periods of 'two pendulums swinging a t the same place. n t, = the difference of the periods of the same pendulum when swinging a,t different places, and representing tho pendulums by capital letters and the places by expononts, as Au=the period of pendulum A a t Ba.ltiniore, Bw=the period of pcndulunl 13 a t Washington, froni the work before the interchange we have
AU-BW=nt,+ nt,

A W - B B = nt,- nt, (2) These equations will give n t, and at,. The period of A is greater than that of B a t the same place, and the period of the same peridulum is greater a t Baltimore than a t W a s l ~ i ~ ~ g t o n . From the direct comparison a t Wasllington nre get A w - B w = nt, Thi~ value serves as a check on the value of nt, derived from t.he interchange, and it 8180 gives us a criterion to judge of the consistency of the values of n t, from equations (1) and (2) by its substitution therein, but it throws no new light on the mean value of nt,, ailice i t must be substituted in equations which have already given this value. For each swing the pendulums were used in the direct and reverse positious, and both chronometers mere used, so that we have four values for each pair of pendulums. These inay be combined in different ways for the sake of comparing results obtained under like conditions ax regards chronometers, positiou, etc. Moreover, the mean values for each pendulum may be treated by deducing values of nt, from the separate consideration of the periods of the different pendulums in the same place and by deducing values of nt, from the same pendulums in different places. The mean results of n t, and at, from these separate treatments will of course be the same. Subtracting the differences An - B Wand AW - BVin the times of oscillation of the two pendulums a t the two*stations before and after the interchange, we have which terms represent two independent determinations of the relative force of gravity by the transportation of both pendulums from one station to the other. Adding the differences, we have (AB- BB)+ (A" - BW) (4) in which case the terms repreeent a comparison of the pendulums in two different places. I n both the above casm by taking the mean we of course arrive a t the same result which we would have obtained by solving equations (1) and (2). The second term of (4) was determined by direct experiment. We therefore have two values for tlie difference of period of the two pendulums, but s i ~ ~ c tho e difference of gravity must bo obtained from equation ( 1 ) and (2), where we have from (1)

The observations a t Baltimore were made by Mr. F. A. Wolff, jr., those a t Washington being made by myself. Tlle apparatus mas set up and the electrical connections arranged a t both places by Mr. Wolff, who also made a complete reduction of the work. This has been checked by Mr. Put~iam and myself. The periods of oscillation were reduced to an infinitely small arc, to a temperature of 240 C. (a mean value), aud to a pressure of 500m111 a t 00 0. The constants employed mere slightly different from those previously used end given in Appendix No. 15. They were chauged by a subsequent discussion, but the temperature varied so little during the time of experiment arid the pressure mas maintained so near the standard dopeed that either set of constauts mould have answered for tho reductions. A corroction for "lag7'-that is, for the difference of temperature, betmeen that indicated by the thermometer and that actually existillg in the pendulum-has usually been applied to work of thie kind. I n the present case, liomever, this quantity is without any real influence, because it is insignificant when compared with errors of reading and graduation. The difference in the time of oscillation of tho three pendulums is entirely without influence on the values of nt, in the three sets. I n passing from Washin-n to Baltimore the length of the period is increased by only one hundred thousandth part of itself, so that even if the pendulums differed in their times by 0-001"his would not influence the above results. A s a matter of fact, they differ by only one-tenth of this. Assuming the value of g a t the Coast Survey Office to be 980.098 dynes, the value a t the Johns Hopkins University would be 980.083. The value of the difference of gravity between the two places is known with much greater accuracy than the absolute value a t Washington; indeed, the absolute value of gravity is not known anywhere to the degree of precision indicated abovo, and can not be so knowu with the appliances now a t our disposal and by using the present methods. It is assuming all that is warranted by work hitherto done to state the absolute value of g at Baltimore as 980.08 dynes. Since in general only one swing was made with each pair of pendulums before and after the interchange, a comparison of these results would hardly form a means of judging of the ability of the pendulums to repeat themselves under similar conditi'ons.

I n the case where tho value for A is twice as large as for B, that is, when a metre peudulum is employed a t one place and a quarter-metre one a t WG otlior, the value corresl~ondingto 2 At, i l l the solution of equations (1) and (2) would be composed of two parts, oiie of which would be twico as large as the other and would be LI t, from tlie A pendulum, the remairlder being At, from the B pendulum. There would, however., be no way of finding tho respective values of n t, from o simplo interchange of positions. Within tho limits of the United States, say from latitude 260 to latitude 490, the greatest change of period of a peiidulum would be about one thousandth part of itself (more exactly, 0.00; 03G). Hence, if quarter-metre pendulums are employed, the value of 6A would be 0.000 518". If the pendulums differed in their periods by one tllousa~idth of a second, the value of 8B mould be 0.000 519% I n this case the assumption that cfA and dB aro equal would involve an error of half a unit in the sixth place of decimals. This would make it necessary to have the difference between tlle periods of A and 13 not greabr than one five-hundredth part in order to have the sixth decimal place accurate in the result fqr nny determinatioii within the latitudes given. of one The efi'ect of a change of elevation on the force of gravity is such that the above li~nit thousandth of the period would not be reached ill any mountains in this country, tlie change in gravity being the same for 15 feet of elovatior1 as it is for one minute of latitude between 250 and 490, viz, 0.000 00144th part of itself. This does not take any account of the matter lying between the upper and lower station, but is purely the effect of the i~icreaseddistance from the earth7s center. We can therefore Bay that for all work in the United States it is sufficient and necessary that the quarter.metre pe~idulumsemployed in the telegraphic method of finding differences of the of a second in their periods. force of gravity should not ditter as much as one thousa~ldth S, EX. The telegraphic determination of the difference of the force of gravity between two places by simultaneous oscillations gives rise to two methods of t r e a t m e n t t h a t of differences and ratios. The following is a statement of these methods, with an application of the data already given in the case of one set of pendulums, A, and B,. In considering the ratio of the times of oscillation of the pendulums we shall treat this quantity as A + B. The ratio of the places will be taken as the time of oscillation of the pendulum a t Baltimore divided by the time a t Washington. . It may be mentioned, although the fact is evident from the interchange, that in order to bring out the factors composing K, we introduce precisely the quantities B" and AW, which are directly observed in the new position, and which determino the value of K?. There is still another way in which the observations may be combined. Although viewed from a different standpoint, it leads prccisely to tho same result. Inasmuch as the entire operation consists essentially of oscillating each of the two pendulums a t each place, wo may simply compare the times of the oscillations in the two places for the difference of gravity and tho tixnes of the two pendulums in tlie same place fbr the difference of the pendulnms. STANDARD GEODETIC POSITIONS I N SOUTHEASTEBN ALASKA, DEPENDING ON ASTRONOMIC OBSERVATIONS MADE DURING- 1892, 1893, BhTD 1594.
By C. A. S C I I O ' ~ Aaeistnnt. , Roports of Docomber 27, 1893, March 28 and August 7: 1894.

REPORT OF DECEMBER 27, 1893.

I have the lionor to present herewith the results of tlie difference of longitude between Tacoma, Wasli., and Sitka, Alaska, also. between Sitka and Yakutat, Alaska, from observations made in 1892 and computed a t the office by Mr. D. L. Hazard. For the purpose of determining the longit~ides of certain standard stations in Alaska, to begin with, two chroliomotric expeditions were fitted out in 1892, one to fix the longitude of tlio astronomic station at, Sitka, the chronometers being carried on board the Pacific Coast Steamship Company's steamer Queen, the other to fix the longitude of the astronomic station 011 Khantaalr Island, Yakntat Bay, the chronometers being carried 011 board the Coast and Geodetic Survey steamer Hassler. Betweeri June and September the Queen made six round trips b e t ~ ~ e eTacoma ii and Sitka,, and between May and September the Hassler made seven round trips between Sitka and Yaklitat. A t Tacoma transit observations for time were made by Assistant J. F. Pratt. He used meridian telescope No. 13 (aperture S&Cm) and observing (Sid.) chronometer Hutton No. 207. There mere also kept At the 'observatory and rated by comparisons the auxiliary lnean tiiue clironometers Frodsham No. 2490 and Hutton No. 231. A table of the resulting chronometer corrections and rates is given in Supplement A. July 18, chronomotcr Huttou No. 231 was transferred to the Queen. ' A t Sitka transit observatiol~s fbr time were niade by Subavsistarlt I?.Morse. B e used merid(Sid.) (:hrono~neterHutton No. 194. There were ian instrument No. 1(aperture ' i O 1 l 1 ) and observil~g also kept a t the observatory and rated by compa~isons the auxiliary (Sid.) chronor~leter Frotlsh:lm No. 3479 and (M. T.) chronomotor . Fletcher No. 2707. A table of tlie resulting chroiloineter corof tho rections and ratas i8 given in Supplement 13, and the rate of' tho clironomot,er es a fuiictio~~ temperatmure is graphically represented. Additional observations for time wero made on tho sun by rneans of a vertical circle and u sextant. At Khnntaalr Island, Palrutat, transit observations for time were uiade by~Assistant J. H. Turner. He nsejecl liieridiaii telescope No. 1 G (apertureG.GOnl) and observing (Sid.) chronometer Bond S ; Son No. 380. Thero wero also ltopt a t tho observatory and rated. by co~nparisons the auxiliary (M. T.) chrononieter No. 49G9 and (Sid.) cliro~io~neter No. 357. A table of the resultingchronomoter correctioll~and rates is given in Supplen~ent C. Between July !) and Augnst 31 wo have cl~ronograpliic record. Some supplementary observations of the sun, for time, were ~nado with a vertical circle and a Loricux sextant, but tlie former were not needed. The party a t Pa,kntnt 13ily mas in cl~argo of Assistaiit J. E. McGrath. Tho nsunl precautions for protecting the timelreepers from undue exposure wero taken. A11 comparisol~swere made by me;uns of coinuitlencos of bents, and mlie~ii l l 1)ort a t any of' tho above three pl;~c:es tlio cornparison with the local time mas effected by means of' a Iiaclr, the chronometers renlaining 011 board. The instruinents on the Qzcee?~. were in charge of Mr. T. D. Davidson; those on the ITassler in charge of Lieutenant Chase, U. S. I S . The two steaulers were a t Sitka a t the same time each trip.

74

UNITED STATES COAST AND GEODETIC STJltVEY.

The method of reduction of tlie observations for longitude was as follows: The traveling or sea rates of the chronometers were deduceti from the comparisons a t the observing or first station, made just before starting and irninediately after the roturu thereto, for each trip, the accumulated rates while a t the second station having been deducted. Thus, each chronometer for each round trip furnishes a result for 1ongit.ude. Similarly, as furnishing another combination, the starting and returning is made fro111 the secontl station, but in this case instead of n, all-round trips, there will be oi~ly n - 1. The advantage of making these two co~nbinations lies i11 this, that the presence of any consistent accelerated (or retarded) rate would be indicated by the results, and i t serves to some extent as a check to the computations. To t h e n - 1results that deduced from the first outer and the last return trip can be added, thus making uso of all observations. To get s measure for the reIative performance of the timekeepers and accordingly to assign weights to tho results by the seveial chronometers, their variations in rates during the several trips were made the criterion. Thua, let l,, &, 4 . . . . I,, be the values for the difference of longitude for the different trips by any cl~ronometer,and let 1 be its mean value; then the weight p to the chronometric result is giveu by - 1) p = )t -. (n [(I where n = number of round trip8 and x it constant introduced for tho sake of convenience. The resulting difference of longitude of each round trip was further subject to weighting, dopending on the duration of the trip, and was taken iriversely proportional to the number of days consumed. A further refinement for (roughly) taking iuto account the loss in time occasio~ied by unfavorable weather for transit observations, in which caso the rate of the observing chronometer had to be depended on, is readily rnade by adding this interval to the days of actual travel. The symmetry of the arrangement .was interfered with toward the close of the work by exchanging or transferring certain chronometers from one steamer to the other. The object was to strengthen the result fkom the last round trip between Tacoma and Sitka. It had, however, the effect of rendering the results from the two determinations (longitudes of Sitka and of Yakutat) to some extent dependent upon one another as t o weights of the chronometers carried in both expeditions. DESCRIPTION OF LONGITUDE STATIONS.

A t Tacoma, Wash., the astronomical station of 1898 was established by Assistant Prrttt in the northeast corner of Wright Park. It is connected with the triangulation of Puget Sound. A t Sitka, Alaska, the new astronomical station was located i n May, 1892, by Subassietant Moree. Tho older stations of 1867,1869,and 1874 were on the Parade Ground,* and that of 1880 on Japollski Island,t but in 1892 these locations were found undesirable fbr various reasons. Tho new station is in front of the Presbyterian church,on an outcroppirig ledge. A pier of brick :md cement was constructed and capped with a block of granite. A t tlie close of the season tho pier marks. Assistant Davidwas left staiiding. Its position is further secured by a nuinber of wit~iess son's station of 1867 (also of 1869) was relocated and found to be nearly 33.6 metres south and 21.8 metres east of the 1803 station. These liurubers correspond to n 9 = 11'.06 and A 1 = 11'.30 to reduce the old to tlie new ~tatiou. The station of 1874 mas also on the Parade Ground, in fi'ont of the officers' quarters. It is not identical with, though near to, the station of 1867-69. A t Yakutat Bay the astronomical station of 1892 was located on the narrow strip of land known as Turriers Poiut, a t the southeastern end of IChantaalr Island, Port Mulgmve. It is to the northwest of the Indian village and soparated from it by a sriiall lagoon. A pier mas built of brick laid in cement arid surrnoulited by a stone cap. It is supposcd to be sufliciently off the beach not to be disturbed by the minter storms. The positio~l is :dso secured by two reference marks (copper bolts in rocks). The Dall and Baker aetronornical station of 1874 $ was southeasterly of the 1892 station and nearer to the orid of the point of land. It is nearly 204 metres, or 911.50, south, and 301 metres, or 19/'.l'i, east of the new station, according to Assistarit Turner's topographic survey.

r = - Oh48 - 0.192 (t - 580.85)

The steamer Hassler, after receiving the Greenwich noon signals on April 25 and April 28, 1892, a t Port Townsend, as telegraphed from the Mare Islaud Navy-Yard, Cal., started from that port for Sitka with fourteen chronometers on board. A short stop was mado a t Port Simp~on where a set of transit observations mere made by Ensign H. C. Poundstono, May 6, for a determination of the longitude of this place. The Hassler reached Sitka May 14. The sea rate of any of the chronometers was then unknown, aud ti first trial mas made for determining h Sitka, using the mixed rates as found a t Port ~ o w n s c n d for Sid. chronometers 380 and 387 and M. T. chronometer 4969, the stationary rates as found a t Sitka for Sid. chronometers 3479 and 194 and M. T. chronometer 1707, and tho rates for M. T. clirouometers 1327,1347, and 1745 were made to depend on the rate curve, a function of temperature as determined a t the Mare Island Navy-Nard. The results from this proceeding proved unsatisfactory, and a second computatior~was made, employing the sea rates as'found from tho first round trip from Sitka to Yakutat, but omitting the six chronometers first named as of little importance. The results for A Sitka and those for Port Simpson worked out by this second more satisfactory method are as follows :

REPORT OF MARCH 28, 1894.

I have the honor to submit herewith tho results for difference of longitude of three stations in southeastern Alaska, in continuation of what was done last year for the establishment of certain standard positiolis in the Territory. The differences of longitude determined in 1893 are tho result8 of chronometer transportations from and to Sitka, as the standard station, and comprise the astronomical and geodetic stations Taku, Fort Wrangell, and Burroughs Bay. Tlie method of reduction is the same as that adopted for last year's work and is fully explained in my report of December 27,1893. The office computation was made by Xr. D. L. Hazard. Tinte observations a t Sitka.-The transit observations more made by Subassistant F. Morse, a t the Parade Qround station of 1892, with meridian telescope No. 16, between May lG and August 25, 1893. This instrument is one of tlie larger meridian telescopes and needs no further description here. Transits mere noted over nine lines. Tiinn was kept by observing chronolneter Hutton No. 104 (sidereal). Daily comparisons mere made with M. T. chronometer No. 1713 and sidereal chronometer No. 1458. Tinte ob~ervationsat Taku.-Meridian telescope No. 9, one of tlie slnaller insfrumonts, was used for the determillation of time; Aid 0. B. French, observer (11. G. Ogdeu, chief of party), from May 16 to Septembcr 1, 1803. T_rsnsits were notod over five liues. Time mas kept by observing chronometer Fletcher No. 1607 (N. T.) between May 16 and 81. After that time sidereal ohrononleter Eutton No. 202 was used. M. T. chronometers Huttoll No. 231 and Nogus 1542 wero compared a t the statioii and kept rated. Tinze obse~.z?atio?ts a t Port Wra?tgell.-At this place meridian telescope No. 13 was monnted. E. TittObservations for time wero made by Subassistant Q. B. Putilam and Aid H. O. Lord (0. wann, chief of party) between May 12 and September 9,1893. Though thirteen lines wore ruled on tlie diaphragm, but five were used in the transit work. Sidereal chronometer Negus No. 1771 was observiug chronometer. Sidereal chronometer Negus No. 1841mas compared with i t and rated until June 1,when its mninsprilig broke. On June 17 sidereal chronoliieter Negus No. 1589 took its place. M. T. chronol~ieterHuttoii No. 229 was also rated a t this place, but found very poor. Personal equation mas observed on July 7, and tho observations mado by Lord between July 22 and August 1 woro referred to Putnam, observer. Time observations at Burrouglts Bay.-Meridian telescope No. 7 was used here for time observations betweell May 1 G and September 3,1893; H. W. Edmouds, observer (13. F. Dickens, chief of party). But five of the fifteen liues of the diaphragm mere used. Sidereal chronometer Hutton No. 223 was employed for observing; M. T. chronometer Bond No. 177 and sidereal chronometer Hutton No. 207 wero kept rated; No. 177, however, proved uudesirable. Cl~rononleter transportation on the Uttited States Coast and Geodetic Survey steaqnw Hmalm.The chroriometors on board the steamer were in charge of H. C. Lord (F. Morse, chief of party). Daily comparisons wero made between the nine chronometers carried by tlie Hmaler, and seven round trips wero made from Sitka to the other stations, which wore visited in succession. The resulting differences of longitude were tabulated, following the plan adopted the previous year,

UNITED STATES COAST AND GEODETIC S.URVEY.

viz, first deterniining tho rates from the round trips, starting from and returning to tlie base secondly, cleterminillg tho rates from round trips, starting from and returning to the station, a ~ l d outer station, and combining tho first and last half trip to get an equal nurriber of values. Weights aro made to depend on tlio agreement of tlie results from the several trips, ;md the latter individually received weights depending on tho hum of themeights of the individual chrosomotors carried to tho actual traveling time, inclusive of the interval and on the duration of tho trip, i. e., i~lvergely between the comparisons with the observatory chronometers (three in number) and the nearest time set a t the station.

R E P O R T O F AUGUST 7 , 1894.

I have the honor to report herewith the results of the ,determinationof severaI standard astronomic positions in southeastern Alaska, the observations having been made during 1892, 1893, and 1894. The chronometric longitude expeditions of Alaska in 1892 and 1893 depend for their results on the longitude of Tacoma, Wash. I n May and June, 1894, this place was connected with the telegraphic longitude system a t Seattle, Wash., with the following result from the office computation : Tacoma west of Seattle, 0" 00" 276.169 08.0098 (see Supplement 1). Longitude of Tacoma, 8h Ogn 47".48 ZL 06-08 (see Supplement 2). The results of the chronometric expeditions to Sitka and Yakuht in 1892 are given in my report of December 27,1893, and the results of the expeditions in 1893 to Port Wrangell, to Taku, and to Burroughs B i y are contained in my report of March 28,1894. The latitudes of these stations were likewise reported. Putting the results together, we get the following values for h of standard positions in southeastern AJaska. They are conriected with local trian ylations and they form the basis upon which the survey of this part of Alaska will depend for its geographical positions.

Respecting local deflections in longitude at Tacoma, Seattle, and Port Townsend, me have the geodetic and astronomic difference of Tacouia and Seattle as follows: A A, = 6' 49"-417 and n A, = 278.159 = 6' 47/'.30, hence differential local deflection 2".02, a reasonably small quantity, showing that the deflection a t Port Tomsend is very much larger.

Tr&raph litus nnd bafferiPs.-The length of the connecting telegraph line is 40 miles and is of No. g galvanized wire, grounded at 'l'acoma and provided with a battery of 73 gravity cells a t Seattle. Tittre d ~ l r ~ t t ~ * ~ f i o j ~ . - T sets w oof trnnslts were observed on every night of exchange at an interval of about one hour, and the same stan were observed, weather permitting, at both stations. A set usually consists of ten stars, one-half of the number observed with collimation east, the other with collimation west, and each part containing one azimuth and four time stars, two north and two sollth of the zenith, if practicable. T i r ~excAanps.-They t took place between the two sets of the transit observations, and consist of two or three dozen arbitrary break signals, sent and received at each station. During these exchanges the chronograph was run at double speed. Personal rquafion.-The differential personal equation as deduced from thelongitude results themselves is D - S = - ~ 3 4 2 4 01.008, a large value, but in perfect accord with the value found at Carson City and Lake Tahoe in August, 1893; the first observer giving earlier time. Compufatio?rsa n d results.-The field computations were made by the observers, and the office computation by D. L. Hazard. The method of reduction is explained in Appendix No. 8, licport for 1889. Transmission or wave and armature time.-Omitting the value of May 21, we have for the transmission time @003 & . c'.ooo5. Location andstation nrarRz.-The astronomic station at Tacoma was located in 1892 by Assistant J. F. Pratt. I t is in the north end of Wright's Park, on the east side, near G street, and in the prolongation of First street south to the west. The pier is on a small knoll and is a few paces north of the park walk; it is dressed to 24 by 15% inches at the top and has cut on the upper surface : S. C. & G. S. There is a copper bolt to mark the station, as described by Assistant Pratt. Assistant Davidsqn placed a granite pier 3% feet long to the south of the observatoryand in the meridian of the transit instrument,498)4 feet distant; and farther south,on the western edge of a spur, a second granite pier, 934 feet from the station, was planted in the same meridian. It is intended that these stones shall serve for a meridian line for the use of surveyors. At Seattle the station of 1888 was used. I t was originally described by Assistant Gilbert in 1886, but was slightly remodeled by Assistant Smith in 1888. It is located in the grounds of the University. Since the location of the University is to be changed, the present grounds may be converted into a city park. Final result for difference of longitude; Tacoma west of Seattle, oh oom 278'159 & O'"J098.

APPENDIX NO. 4-1894.

DISTRIBUTION OF T H E MAGNETIC DECLINATION I N ALASKA AND ADJACENT WATERS FOR T H E YEAR 1895, AND CONSTRUCTION OF AN ISOGONIC CHART FOR T H E SAME EPOCH.

B y C. A. SCHOT'I', AR-istant.
~l~bn~ftt for r d~ , t ~ l , l l c n t i oDvcclnbcr r~ 10. 18D4.

B l a n k page r e t a i n e d f o r p a g i n a t i o n

A P P E N D I X NO. 4-1894.

DISTRIBUTION O F THl3 MAGNETIC DECLINATION IN ALASKA AND ADJAOENT WATERS FOR THE YEAR 1895, AND CONSTRUUTION O F AN ISOGONIC CHAltT FOR THE SAME EPOCH.
By C. A. ~crio'rr, Assistant. Submittod'for publication Decomber 19, 1894.

Prior to the year 1892 our knowledge of the annual change of the magnetic declination was very imperfect over the vast region comprising the coast of Alaska, and still more for the interior. Since that time, however, observations niade by the Coast and Geodetic Survey, especially those in connection with the survey of tlie boundary during the years 1889-1894, as well as information gathered from other sources, greatly aided in assigning ilnproved values to the annual change and in clearing up obscure cases and giving new information a t certain points. I n the higher latitudes the eval~iation of the annual change presents special difficulties in consequence of the paucity of the nlaterial and the comparatively large-diurnal variation which has to be allowed for ill the resulting declination. As an illustration of the change brought about by tho additional testiiilony of late observations, tho case of Sitka may be taken. Here the records up to 1881 and deduced curve given in Appendix No. 7, Report for lSS8, pakes 285-287 arid plate KO.23, strongly indicated decreasing declination for the present time; yet the observations of 1892, 1803, aud 1804, mado a t the same spot, flatly contradicted this inference and established the fact of an increasing easterly declination a t this pl<we,*and consequently also for a considerable region about it. Further proof of an increasing easterly decliriation in southeastern Alaslra was obtained a t Fort Wrangell in 1893. A t Port Simpson, however, no fresh evidence has been fortllcoming since 1885, when a small increase was indicated. I n this region, up to 1892, it was believed that the direction of the magof what was netic needle was eitlier stationary or slightly moving westward. This uncertai~ity going on extended even as far soutll as the State of Washington. Observations had to be specially ordered for Seattle and Tacoma., with tho result that here also the easterly declination was of this motion resulted from a discusfound to be still advancing (May, 1894). Further evider~ce sion of observations collected for Esquirnalt (Victoria), Vancouver Island, between the years 1858 and 1892. A11 this shows that tlie ribbon, shown on the chart in Appendix No. 7, Report for 1888, covering the space of stationary condition of the magnetic needle, ueeds correction and mu$ be locatetl more toward the eastern part of the State of Washington. The dilEculty of ascertsining the annual change for places in Alaska rnay be further illustrated in the CiNe of Yakutat Bay, where the survey of 1892 brought out the fact of a deflection of the needle of 47) a t Khantaak Island, as compared with other places on the bay, and these later observations demanded the cancellation of the annual change of +B1.8 on the isogonic chart for 1890 (constructed in October, 1889)t placed against this locality aud tlie substitution of the words "annual change inappreciable."
I n consequence of this tlio cornpaas placed on the older harbor oharts had to 1)e corrected in tho new insnes by nenrly 1 degree. t Cl~nrt No. 26, i\l~pondixKO. 11, Roport for 1880.

UNITED STATES COAST AND GEODETIC SURVEY. With respect to the interior of Alaska, the most important station where information was eccured in 1889 and 1890 is Fort Yukon, where the declination was fouud decreasing a few minutes per annum, in entire conformity with tho easterly decline noticed to take pl;ace all long tho shores washed by Bering Sea and tlie Arctic Ocean. The fortunate recovery of Bering's magnctic observations made on his first voyage to the coast^ of Kamchatka and eastern Asia in the years 1725 to 1730, and their discussio~i by me in December, 1890 (published in Bulletin No. 20, December 12,1890, and in Appel~dix No. 5, Report for 1891), greatly extended aud improved our knowledge of the secu1;tr variation of the declination in this part of the world and rnodified the a t stations on the opposito or American coast. former values of the annual cl~ange Fully five years have elapsed since tlie production by the Coast and Geodetic Survey of an tho wholo of Alaska Territory and adjacent regions, during which interval isogonic chart coverii~g so much of new information has become available, either in the shape of discovery of old records or of new observations, together with recent discussions, tliat an entire reconstruction of the isogonic chart became a necessity in order that the charts of this territory and tho approaclies thereto may have their compass variations correctly indicated. For this the epoch 1895.0 wak determined upon, Ieaving future improvements to be made for a chart for the year 1900. For the reduction of the observed declinations to the epoch I have made use of all informaor no tion a t present available, resorting to interpolation in regions where oiily an ap~roxri~iiato value for the annual change could be obtained. I t is the uncertainty arising from this circuinstance which determined mc to adopt 1895 rather than 1900 for the epoch. The values adopted for tlie annual change a t thirty-seven localities, distributed over the mllole area are give11 below. inability to procure any, in the western part The entire absence of late observ;ltions, or rather ~r;y of Bering Sea and aloug the coast of eastern Siberia and Karnchatka, rendered it desirable to restrict the geographical extent of the investigation in the west to about 1750 west longitude, as otliern~ise imperfect data near the Asiatic coast would have an itijurious influence on our results. There are two ways of coiistructing isogonic curves-by ineans of a graphical and by means of an analytical process. The former is here out of the question by reason of the large geographic extent involved and the scarcity and irregularity of distribution of the observations. In fact, the of magneticalIy disturbed regions, i. e., graphical treatment is better adapted for investigatior~s for the construction of isabnormal lines or curves of equal anoma,ly. The declination ( D ) (reduced to epoch) a t any place within the spherical surface under oonsideratidn may be expressed as a function of the latitude (p)and of the longitude (A). Tlie form and number of terms of the function adopted is the same as used by me in the preceding invostigati011 in 1889, and is as follows:

where n p = e, - 90, nA = h - Ao, and r, R, t, U, v, w, E , y, z, represent unknown numerical coefficients to be determined from the observations themselves. Terms involving highor powers in g, and A than the third could be dispensed with. The values of qoand A, represent the average latitude and the average longitude of the magnetic stations, respectively, and Dois tho value of the declination corresponding to it. For the latter me take the approximate value D, and find the correction, q, to it; hence .Do= Dl + q. Applying the method of least squares to the i~roblem, the observation equations take the form D1-D+q g,1.r+Al cos q~. 8 91'. t 9 1 A, COB g, u 11' ~ 0 8 '9 V q l R . w + q12 Al cos g , . x + 91h ~ ~ c y o. sy~ $ A13cos3SF, .Z where for shortness we write p1for ng, aud 1 I for n A. Of these equations there are as many as there are observations, but as any large number would be either cumbersome or unmanageable, the observatioris need to be contracted into mean values, i. e., groups or so-called normals. The next step is the formation of the ten normal equations and the evaluation of the unknowns q ... ..-2. The success of the work is to be measured by

+

. +

.

REPORT FOR 1894-PART

11.

91

the degree of approximation between the computed and observed declinations a t the normal places, and the probable error of a single iaepresentation is given by tho formula r =0-674

4-n

VdI-. - -- where - nl,

n = number of normal places or groups, and lcl = number of normal equations. The numodcal dquation expressivo of D being thus established, n sufficient number of point8 for the deliuestion of any isogonic line can rosdily be computed, and consequently tho mholo system of isogonic curves laid down on a suitable chart. The selection of tlie groups depends primarily on the geographic positions of the magnetic stations, but must be such as to cover implicitly the whole area, and wit11 the groups distributed over it in such a way as to give great weight to the coefflcients of the equation determining the declinations. Theoretically, ten groups suffice; but the greater their iiumber the better will be the general representation. O f the xaterial on hand ordy the later observations were introduced, as less liable to error when reduced to the epocli." The data tlre~nselves mere taken from tlie general collection of magnetic observations on file in the Computing Divisior1.t A s usual in the Survey, east declination is expressed by a minus sign prefixed, aud the same sign is give11 the annual increase (a); for s decrease (a) would bo positive. Groups may consist of any number of observod vslues, located sufficiently close together to be uniteti into a me;Lu. Ilere tho numbers vary between one aud fifteen, but the mean values are all takeu nu of tho same weight.

For the western part of Bering Sea this is only roughly indicated by a few lilies fro111 warit of recent data, and tllo same is true for tliat part of the North Pacific adjacent to the Gulf of Alaska where the uncort:tinty in tho declinatio~l is indicated by broken lines. Tliis uncertainty ma,y amount to half a degree, but is not supposed to exceed lo about tlle sonthem and westorn lixnit~of tho curves. I n this part of the North Pacific the malit of recent and reliable observatione is rnucli felt and the annu:tl cllarlgo is unknown. South of latitude 450 and between longitudes 1300 and 1360 about and when a p p r o a c l ~ i ~ the ~ g Tropic of Cancer the lines flntten ont and farther south change the sign of their curvature. Even the earliest observation, that by Captain (look in 1779 a t Karakakoa Bay y = 190 28/, A = 1560001,and the one by Assistant Preston a t the same place in August, 1892 (station called Napoopoo, 9 = 19029/, A = 155059/), when compared, point to tho same direction of change. The singular oval area of west declination lying across tho east coast of Asia, which was formed, or rather left in place, by tho breaking through, about the close of the first quarter of the present century, of tho area of eastern declination across its southern neclr, is apparently elicroaching upon the western part of Bering Sea. Its central maximum declination has increased from 70 to 100 and the agouic line a t its eastern boundary is now supposed to pass in the vicinity of P9tropavlovsk. A t this place, in particular, new observations are needed before reliable results of the distribution of the declination over the westeru Bering Sea can be deduced.

A P P E N D I X No. '5-1894.

THE LENGTH OF THE HOLTON BASE LINE, INDIANA, WITH RELATED EXPERIMENTAL h1EASURES DURING PART OF JULY, AUGUST, SEPTEMBER, AND OCTOBER, 1891; A. T. MOSMAN, ASSISTANT, IN CHARGE OF THE PARTY.

Reported hy CI-IARLES A. SCHOTT, Aseistont.

Submitted for publicntion Auguet 23, 1804.

B l a n k page r e t a i n e d f o r p a g i n a t i o n

A P P E N D I X NO. 8-1894.

THE LENGTH OF THE HOLTON BASE LINE, INDIAXA, WITH ltELATED EXPERIMENTAL MEASURES DURING PART OF JULY, AUGUST, SEPTEMBER, AND OCTOBER, 1891; A. T. NOSMAX, ASSISTANT, IN CHARGE O F THE PARTY.

Reported by CHARLEB A. SCIIOTT, Aaaistnnt. Submitted for publication Auguat 23, 1894.

Introduction.-The Holton base is one of the linear measures which support the transcontinental triangulation. It is located in Ripley County, southeastern Indiaua, distant about 330 kilometres ikon1 the St. Albans base, West Virginia, to the eastward, and distant about 240 kilometres from the Olney base, Illinois, to the wsstward. Its middle point is in latitude 390 03/-3,arid in longitude @ o 22l.2 west of Greenwich. The liuo is inclined to the meridian 4 O 0G1.3, tho aziinuth of the north end being 1750 BY.8 (counted from south to west). Tlie length of the baso is 5.501 kilometres nearly, and tlio approximate height above the average sea level 283 metres. Appendix No. 8, Coast and Geodetic Survey Report for 1892, contains u full account of the lneasurement of this base by the observers, A. T. Mosmm, who had general charge; by It. S. Woodward, Assistant, in charge of the mt?:~tiures with tlio bar-in-ice appar:btus aud experilnents with metallic tapes, and by 0. I I . Tittmann, Assistaut, in charge of the coutact-elide base apparatus. This appendix gives the reports of these observers, headed with a preface by the Superintendent. It comprises 174 pages, and renders i t uilnecessary to enter liore into certain detail matter already stated or discussed in that place, except whon directly coniiected with the base lneasurell or couipntations. The primary base liues heretofore measured by the Survey, as well as all other lengths determiued by it, depend for their unit on tho Committee metro of 1799, tlie property of tho American Philosophical Society of Philadelphia, but this unit of length was superseded in 1890 upon the receipt by tho United States of tho National Prototype metres. The Holton baso is the first prominent one which depends for its length on this new standard unit, and in consequellce an accoutrt must be given here of some intermediate operations, introduced with e view to express the measured length of the baso in terms of the prototype. For this purpose a new and most accurate base apparatus was designed and brought into use by Assistant Woodward, for description of which see Chapter I of Appendix NO. 8. This bar-in-ice apparatus was used for staridarclizing the now contact-slide bars employed in tho measure of the base after its own leugth had been compared with that of tho prototype metre. The same appendix treats a t length of the experiments and results of tape measures. These are of less importance in conr~ection with the Eolton base, but will be found more fully referred to in the report on the length of the St. Albans bnse. The Holtofe base and its measures.-The site for the base was selected by Assistant Mosmali in October arid November, 1890. I t is on a ne:irlylevel table-land between the towns of Holton and
103

104

USITEL) STATES COAST AXD GEODETIC SURVEY.

New Marion, witli its north end about l a kilometri~seast of the former place, and the south end about three-fourths of :I ltilometre north of the village of New Marion. To get the elevation above the eea (about 283 metres) a line of spirit levels connects the base witli the tra~isco~~tinental line of levels which starts fi-om tide water a t Sandy IIook, N. J. The base passes over grassy soil and plowed fields, ant1 in part through woods. A t certain places and times the ground was ~d for the stability of the trestles. found wet and springy, ; ~ i niifhvorable The whole length of tlie base, mith two extra measures of part of it, mas measured twice with the contact-slide apparatus, and 1 kilometre of it also with the bar-in-ice apparatus, going over i t four times. A11 lneasures with the contact bars were with rising temperatures, and in direction one measure of the base was made forward, the other backward. The surface morlurnerits wid subsurface marks of the ends of the base are described and illustrated in Appendix No. 8." Section stones set iu concrete and marlied each witli a fine cross, cut on the head of a copper bolt securecl in it, were placed a t distances of 1.2, 2.1, 3.0, 4.0, and 5.0 kilometres from south end. Stones were also set a t 3.9 and 4.9 kilometres to mark the end points of the kilolnetres iutended fbr the measure with the bar-in-ice. These stories are marked by spherical-headed bolts in connection with the use of tho so-called cut-off apparatus. A t the camp near JIolton thero was also established under a covered shed a standard 100-lnetre comparator. I t s longth was found from measures mith the bar-in-ice apparatus, and i t served for comparing or testing the co~nbinedlength of tlie coutact-slide bars as well as for ascertaining in particular the length of metallic tapes and for other purposes. I t s terminals were provided with bolts for the cut-offapparatus. For this purpose the ends of the steel rode (subsequeutly numbered 13 and 14)f were cut down to the medial 1)1aneand platinum-iridium plugs, 5.02 metres apart, were inserted. Two Iines on the left-hand and three oti the right-hand plug served for making the micrometric measures wl~entho rods were under observation. The general plau of operation was to compare the two rods through a large range of temperature alternately, as well as a t high temperatures and a t freezing temperatures. This was done by lnountirig the two rods in a zilic-lined trough, side by side, a r ~ dby immersion in a solution of borax water, or packed i n melting ice, as reqnired. A fiecond trough was provided for the case of one rod in ice and the other a t a high temperature. ZL :3 f- 2 The measure o f the Holton base proper.-The base was measured throughout mith contact-slide rods Nos. 13 arid 14, once forward and onco backward, with t w o additional measures over a slllall part of it. During all tllese ~neaslirev tlie temperature mas rising, as indicated by the thermometers ill direct contact with the steel rods, and milch tlie greater part of the worlc was done during bright sunshine. Appendix No. 8,1892, pago 499 and following, contains particulars respecting arid improved secondary (so called) apparatus, referring t.o the agate tho colistructiori of this r~em ends, tho contact slides, index lines, wooden casings, thermometers, covers, gectors, aligning telescopes, trestles, etc. The thermometers Green Nos. 5609 and 6G04 (near rear and front end), were attached to bar So. 13 on opposite sides, and thermometc?rs Green KOS.6606 and 5616 (near rear and front end) were similarly attached to No. 14. On August 28 therrnomcter No. 5616 mas accideritally broken and Green No. 5613 was substituted. The stenis are graduated into half degrees. The correctiolis mere determined in June, 1891, but in August, 18'31,the zero corrections mero observed to have changed. On August 28 they were found in tlie order of the table, -0.22, -0.16, -0.37, -0.32; mean, -0.22; also for 6613, -0.09. The difference of the two results or the valuo -0.14 miis applied as an additionk~l correction to each of the numbers of columli u n l e a ~ ~ mid " the value -Oell to each of tlio numbers in column "new mean." Tho work in co~lrjcctio~~ mith the Holtoll base mas ulicler the general direction of A~sistalit Mosman. When ~neasnred with the contact-slide apparatus contacts nrercmade by Assistant Titt mann, who in these lneasures mas aided by Mr. Hayford, Professor Gore (part of the time), Mr. Pennington, and Mr. Gjkrtsen for alignment, for reading of thermometers and sectors, and for rewrdiug.

the 101 bars 139 to 240, and with an avorage difference of 930 for the 100 bars 1000 to N. B., iu which last caso tho difference in longth amounted to zero. Tho question of the relative temperatures of the rods and thermometers * was inquired into and from experiments mado on August 26,1891, when the length of tho camp hectometre was measure(2 seven times, i t would appear that the rods tsko up changes of temperature faster than tho thermometers; in other wotds, the thermometer indications lag about 00.3 0. To test the buhavior of the apparatus under bright sulishinet the base hectometre was measured five times on Septeniber 21 and eight tirnos on September 22, with tho resnlt that the lag was practically insensible during bright sunshine, being only 03-07. Raspecting any uncertainty in the length of the baso that might arise through lag of thermometer! (with respect to the rods), i t should be remembered that the rods wero standardized under tho same condition of rising temperature as obtained when the base was measured; hence the assignod length of 2 (13 and 14) refers to this (rising temperature) condition and no correction to the deduced length$ of the base is needed. On October 5 and G, 1891, some special observations wore mado for testing the length of the apparatus wlien used during falling temperature, in which case the thermometers sh'ow too high. Tho amount of lag deduced (nearly 40) seems quite uncertain on account of the short distance measured and the small chango of hmperature, only about 20 on the 5tth and no sensible change on the 6th. Tho variations in the deduced lougth of 2 (13 and 14), as found by means of measures of a known distance (as found by the bar-in-ice apparatus), appear quite large, as may bo seen from the tabular values given on pages 492,494, and 495 of Appendix No. 8. These variations are supposed due mainly to tho varying rates of temperature changes. The effect of this on the base measure is supposed to be included in the above probable error of the measure. Any uncertainty in tho zero correction of the thermometers would be felt as a constant error, and estimating it as f 00.03 0. mo would have for one bar ZL .05872mmx '03 and for 1100 bars 4 11.4u1n1. (c) I n the reduction of tho base line to the sea level an uncertainty of ~ L 0 . 6 in ~ the mertsured elevation will correspond to ZL0.53tnm (d) Putting togother the preceding values of probable errors that of the base becomes

. . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . ' . . . . . . . . . . .

s + part of its length. which is about r The length assigned to the base is yet to be corrected for the small change made, in computing the base and its parts, in the length of tho combined bars, viz, - 550 X .Olmrn or by 6.5""; further, we may substitute the length of the kilometre measured with the bar-in-ice apparatue (999.9966") for the length derived from the contact-slide apparatus (99g09968"),but the correction is uncertain. The length of the base beco~nes 650.809". Reduction of the lengtl~of the base to sea level.-No great eleva.tions or depressions occur on the line. The range in height is but 219 feet, and in general the ground rises in proceeding from south to north. The north end of the base is 9.0 feet, or 2.743", above its southern end. The average elevation of the line above its south end is 14.44 feet, or 4.401". Bench mark LXVII of the transcontinental line of spirit levels3 ma8 connected with the north end of the base by levehg. This operation was performed by Mr. J. S. Siebert, who measured forward between June 16 and June 22 and backward between June 23 and 27,1891. He found difference B. M. LXVII and north base = 429.77 feet, and north base and B. M. LXVII = 430.03 feet, respectively; mean difference, 429.90 feet, or 131.04 metres; hence height of north base 150.61m 131.04m,and of average base 283.31". Adding to this 3.80 feet or 1.16 metres for height of bars above ground and subtracting 2 feet, or 0.61 metres, for correction to height of bench mark LXVII, we get for height of base above the sea 283.86"; hence reduction to sea level - 0*2455", a n d the final result for length of base becomes 5500-6G4", and its logarithm 3,740 4073. f4 &3

This is the length of the base as marked by the base monuments, but the triangulation station "south base" was Glum inside the line; hence length of base for introduction to the triangulation 6600.568mand its logarithm 3.740 4068 4 4 43 The steel tape measures o f the Holton base.-During part of August, September, and October, 1891, certain experimental work was undertaken a t the Holton base,'having for its object the inquiry into the practicability of the .application of long metallic tapes for the measure of base lines of precision. These researches were conducted by Assistant Woodward, whose report on the results reached will be found in Appendix No. 8, 1892, pages 413-434. Brietly stated, the operations consisted in standardizing two 100-metre ssteel tapes, under given teusion and temperature, on the camp hectometre, and these were in turn used for the measure of the Holton base. The six sections of the base were measured from six to thirty times each, under various circumst.&nces,as to temperature, state of weather, day or night, ek., and the behavior of' the ta,pes was especially show11 by the numerous measures of the base kilometre. Hero t l ~ e advantage a tape measufe has over a bar measure could he fully realized- that is, the tape could be standardized a t its total length and the nleasures of the base could be multiplied to a great estent without much cost when once the line had been prepared for tape measure. Thus the probable error of the long unit could be made extremely small and the mere error of measure of the base could be reduced to a minimum. The presence of constant errors are therefore those most to be feared with tape measures. Assistant Woodward adopts the length of the camp hectometre :b8 follows (page 423 of Appendix 8):

The thirty tape measures of the base kilometre afford an excellent means for judging of the practical outcome of such measures. It will be noted that the day measures of October 3 and 7 give results largely in error, whereas the mean of the night (evening) measures is fairly correct. Further attention may be called to t,hho substantial agreement with each other and with the triie value of the measures of the base kilometre from the two tapes, their disagreement boing less than the millionth part of the length of the line. Assistant Woodward concludes from the measures of the standard kilometre that the temperatures of the tapes when uscd a t night in the open air were substa.ntially as well defined by the mercuriaI tl~ermorneters as when the tapes were used under the slled of tho 100-metre camp comparator, and he further points out that as a rule the day measures give results relatively too short. be nsed, though with less confidence, if we adopt the equaSuch measures call ~levertlieless tion of tho tapo to tho special condition of d i ~ y (sunshine) measures. When this is done the results may be combined with tho results of tho night or after-sundown measures. To effect this the length of the tape, to make it suitable for d i y measure, must be take11 0.74n11u longer than its value adopted for night measures. The following tablo exhibits a comparison betwoen the results by the bar and tape measures of the length of the several sections of the base. Two sets of results are givon for tho tape measures, one depending solely on the night (after sundown) measures, the other del~ending on t,he night and day measures after the standard length of the tapes had been changed to correspond to tho case of insolation. Certain results of August 27 and 28 mere rejected as being untrustworthy, and all measures of Soptember 4 were omittiad as affected by a strong breeze, rising to a gale a t intervals.

Taking the night measures alone and forming the differences of each single measure from the mean value of the respective sections, the observer deduces from forty-six measures covering the six sections (excluding a seveuth section of 100 metres) the probable error of a measure of a single tape & 0 . 1 j 5 and ~ ~ the probable error of a single measure by the tape of a kilometre f 1.74m111, which equals nearly don part of the le~lgtli. The probable error of his adopted Iength of the whole base (5500.832m) is given on page 454 of Appendix No. 8 as k3.68mm, which n.early equals r43+-0-bii part of the length. According to the probable errors assigned to tho resultant values of the length of the base by the measures with the contact-slide apparatus and with the tape apparatus i t mould appear that the two measures are of about equaI value and each subject to a probable error of about part of the length.* This shows part of the length, whereas they differ by 17mm,or about H+O-oT that the assigned probable errors can not be depended upon, and the prevalence of minus differences in the above table would indicate the presence of some c o n ~ t a n error t or errors not taken into account. So far as triangulation is concerned, even an uncertainty of one three-hundredtho~sandt~ part h mould not be considered excessive. The great differerlce in the n~easllres of the l m t 600 metres, which amounts to d6 part, nearly, is remarkable, especially since the eeparate measures agree well among themselves. It mould seem quite plain that the great accuracy apparently reached with the tape apparatus must in any case depend on the close attention paid by the observer to the minutest detail involved in the operation as well as upon favorable atmospheric conditions during the night measures. There appears to be no good reason why the results obtained by the bars and tape sllould not be united to a final resuIt for the length of the Holton base. The difference in the results, however, indicates the presence of constant errors; hence the taking of the simple mean value is indicated. The two measures were not made a t the same level. I n the case of the tape measures we have their average elevation above south base about 4.gm, and with north base 2.61m above south base, and allowing 0.61m for the correction of the line of spirit levels, we obtain tho average height of the tape, 283.33" hence the reduction to sea level, - 0.2450m,and the length of the base, 5500.387m. The mean length, 4 (5500.664 + 5500.687), equals 6500.576m4 8.4m1n. The probable error is of course very uncertain, but may be taken as part of the length. The base to be introduced in the triangulation is therefore 5600.570m, and its logarithm 3.740 4077 0. zt 8 & 66

Tho differenoe amounts to 23mm as finally given.

THE LENGTH OF THE ST. ALBANS BASE LINE, WEST VIRGINIA, MEASURED IN OCTOBER, 1892, R. S. WOODWARD, ASSISTANT, COAST AND GEODETIC SURVEY, IN CHARGE OF THE PARTY.
Reported b y CHARLES A. SCI3OTT. Assistant.
Submitted for publicatio~iSoptomber 20. 1804.

A P P E N D I X NO. 6-1894.

THE LENGTH O F THE ST. ALBANS BASE LINE, WEST VIRGINIA, MEASURED IN OCTOBER, 1892, It. 8. WOODWAItD, ASSISTANT, COAST AND GEODETIC SURVEY,
I N CHARGE O F THE PARTY.*

licportod bg C I I A ~ ~ LA. E S SCIIOTT,Aseistnnt. Sobmittod for publication Septembo- 26, 1894.

--- - - - ---- -- --"For e full nocount of the meaauroment and r08lllt8, seo the observor'e report, Appendix No. 8, Report for 1892, peg08 466-474, and for tho theory of metallio tape measures, pages 480-489. 119

Introduction.-The St. Albitns base line forms part of the trai~scontinental triangulation near tho thirty-nillth parallel of latitude. I t is situated ill the valley of the Great Kailawha River, near the village of St. Albans, in Kauawha County, w. Pa. The neaiSestbase iu this triangulation, to the e:lstward of it, is tho Kent Island base, Rfaryla~rd, distant from it about 045 kilouletres as measured ill tlie axis of the triangulation, and to the westward nre h:tve the Holton baaa, Iutliatla, about 330 kilouietres distult. Tho middle point of' the base is ill latitude 38O 23'4, and in longitude 810 48l.9 west of Gree~iwicli;tlle aziti~utlr, east end to west eud, is 108O 03'-9 (countetl from the south westward). The length of the base is liearly Y.S;O ltiloli~etre~, and it lies about 180 metres above the average surface of the ocean. Tho line betweell tho end points is nearly level throughout. Tlris is the second base of precision the measure of which was effected by means of metallic tapes, aricl the first one where the tape meesures wore elnployed exclusive of otlier means. The experinlcut~l work a t the Holtori bitso, Indiana, iu tllo proceding Year, illvolved the question of the comparative merits of the cotitact slide apparatus a11(1of the ht1)e 81)p;\1'9t~~, when used for precise measures, and i t was concluded that results by tllo latter could be fully trusted in those cases in which the requisite minute attention is paid to all circulllstallces wliich have or may have influeuce on tlie result. Among tlicse influences tile condition of the atmosphere is the most potent, and measures made after suudown or during [light timu wero considered as made under more favorable circumstances than day measures. For a com1)lete u~~derstarlding of the use of metallic tapes for the itbore purpose no better reference be given than tlie report of Assistant It. S. Woodward, by whom the method was developed 011 tile Survey. (See Appendix No. 8, Report fbr 1892.) Tlie base was located in the summer of 1891, by Subassistant W. B. Fairfield. Tho terminal stones were set and the profile of the line and its connectioll with the height of the triangulation were ascertained under the direction of Assistant A. T.Mosman. The ground a t west base is 0.5 metre below the top of the stake a t east base. I n October, 1892, the base wa8 measured by the Party in charge of Assistant R. S. M7oodward. The line had been cleared of obstacles; and the lnerlrillg and supporting stakes for the tapes had

120

UNITED STATES COAST AND GEODETIC: SURVEY.

been placed throughout its length. These stakes were set 10 metres apart, aligned and cut to slope for each tape length. A 1 measures were made between October 10 and October 14; of these, one was merely experimental for training tho party to the manil)ulation. Four were made a t night and one during bright sunshine, but this latter was not em~~loyed for determining the length of the base. Of the four effective measures two were forward and two were backward Inea,sures by means of the steel tapes Nos. 85 and 88, previously employed, and standardized a t the Holtoxl camp and base, Indiana. The dimensions of theso tapes are, length, 101.01 metres; cross section, 6.34 by 0.47 millimetre; their weight i s 22.3 grammes per metre of length. The end graduations fall about half a metre from the tape ends; when not in use the tapes aro rolled up on reels. A s stated in Appendix No. 8, Report for 1892, and in my report on the length of t.he Holton base, Indiana (of August 23,1894), the standard lengtl~s of the tapes were found by repeated measures of the l~ectometre standard a t the Holton camp, which length was laid down by means of the barin-ice apparatus. The length of this bar, kuown as B17, was found to be ti metres - 18.0 microns in 4 1.1 terms of the iriternational metre and when a t the temperature of molting ice, as determined by Assistant Woodward and Mr. Siebert; and the lengths of the tapes aro given as*

mm. mm. nz. m . nim. Ta = 20 B17 + 3.86 + 1.0947 t or T8,= 100 + 3.50 + 1.0947 t TflR = 20 Xi1, + 6.31 + 1.0914 t T a n = 100 + 5.95 + 1.0914t
This is for the standard temperature of 25 pounds 9 ounces and for the temperature t of the centigrade scale (referred to hydrogen). During the measure of the base the actual tension applied was but 25 pounds 6 ounces, which shorten8 the length of each by 0.14"'"'. In all measures Assistant Woodward was the observer a t the front end, and Assistant Haskell a t the rear end, and the thermometers from which the tape teniperature mas inferred were read by these observers. The base was divided into four sections, representing approximately kilometres excepting one section of about 869 metres. The fractional part of a tape was obtained directly from the 20-metre subspaces of the tapes, and a remaining portion of 9 metres was measured by means of an auxiliary 15-metresteel tape, divided to millimetres. The several positions of the tapes were marked on zinc plates left in position throughout the measures, the marks on which form part of the record. Reepecting grades, the greatest difference in height of the plades for any tape length was 3.571 metres. The corrections to the thermometer readings during the base measures are as follows:

These thermometers were provided with sheaths of thin steel tape slipped over their bulbs, in the hope of securing thereby a close approximation to the actual temperature of the tapes. Two thermometers were read when placed a t a distance of 10 metres from the ends of the tape; the third was placed a t the hiddle. The index correction to tho spring balance measuring the tension of the tapes was ascertained on five days between October 10 and 21.

APPENDIX NO. 7-1894.

MANUAL
PART 111.

TIDES.

SOME CONNECTIONS BETWEEN HARMONIC AND NONHARMONIC QUANTITIES, INCLUDING APPLICATIONS TO THE REDUCTION AND PREDICTION OF TIDES.
B y R O L L I N A. H A R R I S . Submitted for publioation December 28,IW.

B l a n k page r e t a i n e d f o r p a g i n a t i o n

PREFACE TO P A R T 111.

The following pages have been prepared for tlie purpose of supplying some of the immediate marits of the Tidal 1)ivisioli. They constitute Part X I 1 of a proposed manual of tides, the plan of which limy be outlined thus: Part I. History of' tides, including old methods of treatment. P a r t 11. Tidal observation, eqnilibrium theory, and harmonic analysis. P a r t 111. Connections between bal.monic and nonharlnonic qu:lutities. Part IV. Tidal theory aud astronolnical quantities deduced from tidal observations. P a r t V. Tidal c.urrcnts. Tables. Auxiliary tables and a collection of tidal constants, includirig cotidal charts. As no considerable portion of the material co~stitutillg Part 1 1 1is olsowhere available, it has seeilied desirable to publish i t in advance of Parts I and 1 1 ,whose subject-matter hrts been largely treated in various publications. Tllo object of this paper is, iu a gelieral way, indicated by its title; but it may not be out of place to colnrnellt here upou certaiii of its aims arid features. Owing to a lack of reasonably precise dotinitions and adequate modes of reduction, the nonharmonic constants (i. e. those referring to high and low water) liave too often been of little service where an accurate and satisfactory ltuowledge of the tide mas desired. It .is true that quite accurate prudictious have been made, based upon the tables resulting from nonharnionic discussions; but i t is to be observed (1) that the tables so used were designed chiefly for particular stations and so mere of little or no use generally; (2) that 10llg series of ~bservationswere necessary for the construction of such tables; (3) that most nonharmonic discussio~lshave b w n confined to s t a t i o ~ ~ where s the diurnal inequality is so small as to give 110 serious trouble. The present attempt to overcome these objections provides an approrimate method of analyzing a siiigle month's observations upon high and low water for obtainillg both tlie harmonic and the nonharmonic constants, regardless of the amount of diurnal inequality, slid \\rithout difficult computations. It also provides tables for the anJ y s i s and prediction of tides, designed for general 1160, regardless of the location of the station. Little atkiltion has heretofore been given to the classification of tides for the purpose of selecting the best possible port of reference for a given subordinate station, proximity in geographic position having been the sole criterion with few esce~tions. Now, i t is believed, are given for the first time such harmonic and nonharmonic criteria as will readily show how the types of tide a t different stations compare. I n this connectioll are given rules for referring one station to another. The chaptor entitled "Prediction of Tides describes a proposed tide-predicting .machine combining the merits of the Thomson and the Ferrel machines; a general graphic process enabling one (by means of a set of curves constructed once for all from the harmonic constants of the given station) to predict tides without a machine and without computation, the amount of work involved depending upon the accuracy desired; also an approximate arithmetical method for predicting high and low waters from certain tidal constants.

"

127

UNITED STATES COAST AND GEODETIC SURVEY. By correlating harmonic and nonharmonic quantities a better insight into tides is obtained may be inferred than from the consideration of either alone. I n this may observable phe~lomena froni harrr~olricconstants, i~lconsistenciesmay be detected, and Inissing quautities supplied; also particular values of ~ionhar~rionic quantities may be reduced to their mean values, and conversely. $5 46, 47 are given mainly for the purpose of furnishing a key t o tho study of Ferre17s nonharmo~iicao;tlysc?s. These discussions, covering years of observations, throw much light upon the. nature of' tidal inequalities. The apponded tables, already alluded to, are based principally upon those of Baird and Darwin. Tlie considerablo computation involved in their preparation has bee11 performed by members of the Tidal Division. Their scope differs somewhat from that of the paper accompanying them. This remal k applies especiaUy t o Tables 1to 13, which are designed for the harmonic analysis of tides from hourly ordinates, a subject to be treated in P a r t II. I have to ack~~owledge much assista~icefrom Mr. L. P. Shidy, wl~oso long experience in tidal work has rendered his advice particularly valuable, and whose cooperation has enabled the work to go on.

This also represents thc average depression of the minima; or, it is the averago amplitude or semirange of the compound wave. When there are tixed relations between the speeds of tho componente, the speeds of no two being commensurable with each other, foruiula (18) may still give the semirange of the compound wave, mhilo the average elevation of tilo maxima or depression of tho minima may not be given with sufficient accuracy. 10. Oonditions for n predominating compone)lt. In order to have a simple wave determine the number of maxima and minima whe~l combined with a series of other simple waves, i t is necessary that its greatest slope be greater than the greatest possible slope of tho series. For the two steopest parts of the predominating wave fall so~nemhere up011the serial wave; and the upward and downward slopes st these points cause the resultant curve to slope upward or downward a t these points. But a ma,ximuul or a minimum ilnplies the existence of both an upward and a downward slope. Since the greatest slope of any simple wave is proportional to amplitude + wave-length, the necessyy condition for a predominating wavt is

The mean range, the eprittg range, etc., and the high or loto water inequaZiCy in ibeigl~t. For some purposes it is conveliient to give names to varions ranges of tide. Mean range is the average valuo of tho semidaily range of tide. Spring rallge is the greatest periodic semidaily range, occurring iisuelly one or two days after new ant1 full moon. Neap range is the smallest periotlic seinitlaily range, occurri~igusually one or two days after the moon is in quadrature, that is, after the first and third quartere. Perigean range is the greatest periodic samidaily range of tide, ~ c c u r r i n g lisuully from one to three days after the moon is in perigee. Apo~ean range is the smallest periodic semidaily range, occurriilg us~~:llly from one to three days after tlie moon is iu apogee. Great diu~nal rayle is the difference between tlte mean of all tlio higlier liigh waters : ~ u d the mean of all the lower low waters of each day duri~lg one or Inore half tropical or declinational montl~s.
139

140

UNITED STATES COAST AND GEODETIC SURVEY.

Small diurnal range is t h e difference between the mean of all the lower high waters and the mean of all t h e higher low waters of each day during one or more half tropical or declinational months. Great tropic range is the greatest periodic daily range of tide, uaua.lly occurri~ig soon after the moon is farthest north or south from the equator arld therefore nenr one of tho tropics. Small tropic range is tlie srnallest periodic daily range of tide, usually occurring soori after the moon is farthest north or south from the equator and therefore nenr one of the tropics. Tides determining these ranges, or of aimultaileous occurrence, mity be referred to a s ~pring, neap, perigean, tropic, etc.; a like remark is applicable t o lunitidal intervals, and occasionally to other quantities. Diurnal inequality a s here used generally denotes the greatest periodic difference in height between tmocor~secutive high waters or low waters, usually occurring soon after the moon isfarthest north or south from the equator; this inequality is therefore determined by the tropic tides. 12. 14. The meall range of tide as determined from the tidal coTnponeats i s invarinbly les8 t8an the mean range of tide determined from observed high and loui wntcrs. The diferer~ce between the two determinations is constant from year to year at a given 6tation. In summing for ally cornpollent, tlie curve is read a t fixed times (mliich are determined in advauce) depondi~~g i n no may upon the height of the sea.. I n summing for high aud low waters the tidal curve is actually read a t times whicli coultl be only approximately determined in advance, and which times depend to a considerable extent upon the height of the sea. In the former case the elevatious and depressions other than tl~ose due to tlie colnponerit (with its harrnonics) sougl~t will eventually become eliminated. I n the latter case we have the liberty of selecting readirigs a t about the fixed times of' luaxil~ln of the wave got by cornbi~ling all the tidal components. The mean range of the obscl.vet1 tide will always be greater than that of the theoretical tide. For, in orcler to get this observed range of tidu to agree with that of the theoretical tide, we monld have to observe t l ~ o height of the sea, at tlte theoretical or predictable time8 01'I~iglr, and low water. The magnitude of the discrepaucy j u ~ t pointed out will depend largely upon who observes the tides, aud whether the high arld low -tars are observed upon a staff or are obtained from the record of an autolnatic tide gauge. Let it be assumed that what is meant by high and ?OR water heights are heights obtained from a continuous curve by a tabulator who rends, :LS nearly as hisjudgmelit \trill permit, a curve which will eliminate such irregularit.ies as are obviously not predictable. With this definition of high and lorn waters, aud in want of definite information, the discrepancy may be assumed to bo perhaps 1 per cent of the computed range. For high and low waters as ordinarily tabulated this t s about 2 per cent. discrepancy probably a ~ n o ~ i nto 15. T o compute the hourly i~eight8 of the M tide. To compute spring and neap ranges. The phase wave consists of Sz and p2. 52 conspires with M, st spring tide and interferes a t neap tide. The argument of the pz moon exceeds that of tho S, lnoon by four times the mean longitude of the sun less that of the moon. Therefore, whenever the moon is new, full, or in quadrature, the Sz moon and that of /A, are in conjunction. For .this reason, and assuming that the epochs of Sz and p2 are equal, S2and p2 conspire a t the times of spring or neap tides. The mean range of tide with the residual effect of S, excluded is

28. Determination of mean sea level and long-period tides. Where hourly heights of the tide are given, it is obvions that a suitable period of time for determining meau sea level would be one in which each of the principal tidal components 11ii~lies an integral number of oscillations. By taking mu1til)les of the liourly speed of each component, it is readily seen that the period of 29 meau solar days and zero hours is tlie best value obtainable unless the given herghts of period may be adopted for the the tide are taken a t intervals of less than one hour. Tlie s a n ~ e dcterrllination of nieari sea level (half-tidelevel, § 24) from observations of high and low waters. of mean high and low water for the 29-day This nleitrl se:L level is the half' sum of the lreigl~ts period or group.
