REDUCTION O F PERIGEAN, APOGEAN, AND M I D T I m TIDES.

32. Midtinte tiJcs. A nu~iiber of tides occurri~~g between perigee and apogee, also between apogee and perigee, are tabulated in tlie form headed "Midtime tides" fbr the purpose of ascertaining the relative age of the parallax wave. I t is generally ~ufficielitto begin the tabulation about a day and a half be1'ol.e the niidti~nevand to use on each oceilsion, say, 24 titles, thus covering nearly 6 lunar days. It is necessary to take pairs of ~riidtirllesbecause the age as determined from the ono following perigee may diil'er a day or two from the age as determined from the ouo following apogee. The from Tablo 24, column lieaded "0 tides," phase correction ernployed in this reduction is obtair~ed using the amplitude of Sz uncorrected for K, and T2. The phase correction fiecomes zero for a series about 220 days in length; i. e. when S midtimo groups of the same kind are combined into one. The last column shows the corrected range of tide for the times given in the colunln headed 4' Average." The r~oxt step is to plot tlieso ranges at the proper times-which times are one-half lunar day apart, very ~iearly-and to driaw a curve fitting the plotted values. Since tllese values usually appear as a double row of points, :I third row should be obtained lyilrg midway between theother two. I t may be seen by aid of Table 16 that a parallax inequality whose age is zero and which is !N should causo the rango of tide a t ~iiidtime to be about equal to its mean due to N,,L,, iind . value. Consequently one should mark upon each curve the tilno \rhen the range becomes equal to its mean value taken from tlie first reduction. Tho ti~ues of occurrence of tlieso ranges, diminished by the appropriate midtirnas, give, in tlie niean, the age of the parallax inequality. 33. Perigean and apogean tides. The age of the parallax inequality, when added to tile observatiori times of perigee and apogee, gives the times of groat,est and least parallax effect upon the range of tide. Before and after each of these times copy down, say, G tides, and deterlni~le the perigean and apogean ranges. Table 24, column lisade(1 " 6 tides,'' is employed in maltirig the correction for phase. The high ailcl low water diurnal inequalities are takeu a t the times of greatest and least parallax effect.

REDUOTION O F DECLINA'1710NAL TLDES.

36. Moon near the equator.

Whenever the amplitude of the diurnal wave is small in comparison with that of t h e semidiurnal, we have Iiange of diurnal wave = .\/( I1 W inequality )" ( LW inequality) 2 The mir~imum va.lue of this rauge a.ud the time of its occurrence are found by rnealis of the reduc ti011headed "Minimum diurnal tides." The time of this event diminished by tho observation time of moon on equator is t h e uncorrected age of t h e diurnal inequality, or of 0, relative to K1. I n deterrninii~g t h e minimnm diurnal tide, several days' observations should be used, beginning shortly before the moon crosses t h e equator. The HW iuequality or LW inequality should be made t o change sign whenever either passes through zero. Tho following Ilrocess may be employed : Plbt t h e numerically greater inequality, :tlld thus deterrniue when it becorr~ea zero. The equation of this straight line may b e written y = ntt (133) The lesser inequality when plotted will approximately follow s straight line whose equation is o becomes a minimum when The sum of t h e squares of t h e t ~ y's

I f t h e speed of t h e diurnal w:hve is less than In,, prefix the minus sign to t h e minimum range. The rnil~imurn ranges 'should be taken in pairs in order to eliminate Q, from O1. 37. Moon far north or south. The uncorrected age of the diurnal inequality having been found, increase t h e times of extreme declinatior~thereby, tlius obtaining the times when the ainplitude of the diurnal wave become@a maximum. A t these times tropic tides occur; in tho reduction, one or two or more high waters and a s rnany low waters are taken on either side of each time. It may be noted t h a t for any one determinntiorl of the quantities directly conuectecl with t h e tropic tides, the 1u11itidaI intervals having approxi~netely equal values should be written in the same colurnu. From a reduction of t h e high waters and of the lorn waters, according to the accompanying form, t h e following uncore s obtained : rected q u a ~ ~ t i t i are Ir~tervals, heights, Gc, Sc, Mc, HWQ*, LWQ. Both heights and intervals of the groat tropic tides can alwa,ys be obtained from the reductions; but the sniall tropic tides can not be so obtained where evanescent tides occur. A t auoh places Sc may be roughly inferred from the equation G c + S c = 2 Mn. The tropic rarige of the diurnal wave for a give11 time becomes approximately known by the formula The amplitude D, of tlie semidiurnal wave when t h e moon iu far from tlie equator is approximately equal to dMc-f

At stations where the order of the high waters, sny, is eometimee reversed, even when the moon is far from the equator, a periotl of six months, or some iuultiple thereof, should be used in finding HWQ and X, Q 21. Theee qnantities are reduced to their mean value8 by Chaptor IV. For most stations, the two latter quantities call De found whenever the mooi is near the equator, and especially about the times of the equinoxes. Prom those results are determined the ratio Gc + Mn, the duration of the great tropic range (always take11 to be less than a half lunar day), and whether the tropic high or tropic low water, departs farther from moan sea level. DATUM I'LANES.

42. To determine rc plane of reference, having a given dejinition with respect to the tide, tohen only a few observations are available. It is here supposed that observations, or more likely predictions, simultaneous with the observations in question aro givexi for a neighboring principal station having a similar type of tide; i t is also supposed that the observations or predictions a t the principal station have beon reduced to a plane of reference liavilig the required definition. Determine from tlie observed heights a t the subordinate station s plano approaching the one which definition would require. Call this the approximate plane arid let IL donoto its height above the required plano. Find a r a ~ ~ of g etide by taking the mean of all observed low waters from the mean of all observed high uraters. Let H denote the height of the tides a t the principal station which correspond to the tides used in determining the approximate plane a t the subordinate station. Let
y

IL = r a. The more nearly r remains constant, the better tlie selection of the neighboring principal station. As a general rule field parties are supplied with tide tables giving predictions for the time in question. Now, uuless tlie predicted heights are referred to a plane of reference having the same tidal definition as the oue tc?bo determined, they must be reduced to such a plane by adding a constant which we must suppose to be given in the tido tables. To dispense with this labor, predictions and soundings should be referred to planes having uniform definitions over a considerable area. To avoid confusion, which is sure to result near the limits of each such area,, one . definition should be used the world over. 43.+ To determine mean sea level from one mont1~'s observations.-Use the period of 29 solar days. Take the menxi of avorage high and average low water, or the meall of the hourly ordinates if a continuous record be available. To determine mean low water from one month's observations.-Use the period of 29 solar days. Find the iuean range of tide aiid mean low water for this period. Reduce this range by the factor 3 (Mn), Table 14. Depress the observed mean low water by 4 (mean range - observed ineau range). (I*)
The value of (K, Ol)/M2 which is needed in Table 14 may be inferred from some neighboring station with sufficient accuracy for the present purpose, or i t may be found by means of 4 44. To determine meal&loioer low water from one month's observations.-Use tho period of 27 solar days, i. e. a declinational rnontl~. Mark tho lower low water of each day, and take the mean of tlie values so marked. Subtract this value from muan low water as determined from the 29-day period, and xiiultiply tho result by the factor 1.02 PI,Table 32. Depress the corrected mean low water by the quantity just obtained, and the result will be mean lower low water. no one reducing factor, like This plane of reference is unsatisfactory in accurate work, becamuse 4, applies well to all sti~tions. Tliis is especially truo where the low water inequality (LWQ) is with the high water inequality (HWQ). small in co~nparisoi~

These divided by thedspeed" of the inequality (i. o. the change in x per mean so1a.r hour, say) give the "age of the tide" from times and hoights, respectively. I n all cases we shall assume that x corresponds to the hour of (local) transit of the moon, or to the moon's anomaly, longitude, etc., as the case may be, and not to the timo of high water, low water, or a mean of theso times; otherwise the value of x would correspond to a time a constant amount in advance or in retard of the moon's transit or other astronoluical argument. Ferrel adopted this assumption in his "Discussion of tides in New Pork Harbor."* I n earlier papers, notably i n his "Discussion of tides in Boston Harbornt and in his "Tidal researches,"$ he has not corrected tho e7s and a's for the luriitidal interval. To mako this correction, add the value of the lunitidal interval multiplied by tho speed of the inequality when the e's and a's are affectod with one subscript; use twice this speed when thero are two subscripts, and so on. 47. CHAPTER IV.
TO REDUCE RESULTS TO THEIR MEAN VALUES.

48. A11 tidal components which depond upon the moon are assumed to have slightly variable amplitudes in order to botter adapt them to each year of the luni-solar cycle. Tho reason for this is that if they had fixed amplitudes many additioual components would bo necessary to take into account this irregularity of the tide; moreover, those additional components would have periods differing so little from the periods of the compononts with which they are now combined that a long series of observations would be necesfiary for tlieir independent determination. Besides accou~lting for the small compo~~ents duo to the regression of the moon's node, the variation in the amplitudes may be made to talro into account still other componelits whose speeds are nearly equa.1to the speedti of those components with which thoy are combined. The factors F a n d f,for recluciug the amplitudes of the components obtained from a particular series to their mean vduos and vico versa, are giveu in Tables 10 and 13, which are based upon, or copied from, tho tables given ill Baird's Manual for Tidal Observations. I n Table 14 aro given F for the mean range of tidc,for I<, 0,,aud X, basedupon thofactors of Baird's manualand the nieari values of the coefficients as given in Darwin's roport (1883). Table 14, for reducing the meau range of tide, may be tested by means of the observed ranges a t Boston for tho years 1848 to 1565, Uuited States Coast Snrvey Report, 1868, page 81, Table VIII, last columrl; also a t n'ew York for the years 1856 to 1874, United States Coast Survey lieport, 1S73, page 198, Table V, eighth column. Tlie ratio (RI 0,)/hT2is about 0.2 a t Boston aud 0.3 a t Now York. 4!). Tllo following approximato relations will suffice for reducing reduutioti results to their mean values. In fact, a consideration of tho nature of these relations, together with tlie naturo of the 3"s of tho components, of Mn, El O,, and X, sliows that the left-hand part of these relations lies very near to its mean valuo when the quantities composil~g tlie right-hand part have their respective mean values. To reduce a quantity represented by tho left-hand part to its mean value, observe the corrospo~iding increase, say, in tho right-hand part end apply it to the given quantity, adding or multiplying as tho caw may be. CHAPTER V.
ON THE CLASSIFICATION OF TIDES.

60. For places where coritinuous records of the tides have been obtained for any considerabIe lcngth of time, it is usually possible to ma,ko predictions ba,sed upon the analysis of snch observatioirs. But any tide table would soon become too bulky and expensive if predictions were to be given in detail for every place where forecasts are desired. I t therefore becomes inlportant to find a cla,ssification of tides, with the object of referring all stations having similar tides to one principal station where full predictions are given. The following<assumptions implied in the proposed classification hold true, as regards the principal compouents, for nearly every station where an analysis has been made:

First. Tho intervals of the

diurnal

components are approximately equal to one another a t

any particular station. Second. The amplitudes of the lunar Or "lar semidiurnal components bear approximately diurnal the same ratios to one another a t a11 stations. Granting the truth of these assumptions, the form of the tidal wave depends almost wholly upoll (a) The form of the wave composed of the tropic diurnal wave and the principal lunar semidiurnal component; that is, upon (KI 0,)/ M2 and M20 l C 1 O - OI0. (b) The ratio of tho amplitudes of the principal solar and lunar seniidiurnal component; that i8, upon 82/M2. (c) The form of the lunar semidiurnal wave; that is, upon M4/M2, 2 MzO Md0, M6/M2, 3 MzO Ma0, where, as is nearly always the case, M, and Ma are the principal harmonics of M2. Those quantities being equal a t two stations, the tides a t the one may be inferred. from those a t the other. Not only are tho times and heights of high and low water 6omparable, but also the height of the sea or tide a t any intermediate hour. When only high and low waters are to be 01)/M2 is a comcompared, the quantities in (c) need riot be alike a t both stations unless (K paratively large quantity; in which case the form of the lunar semidiurnal wave should be approximately tho same a t both stations. 51. If nonharmonic constants are used the quantities upon which the form of the tide wave depends are (a1) The ratios of the high and low water inequalities in height to the mean range of tide, together with the sequence of the four tides of a day; that is, upon HWQ/Mn, LWQ/Mn, and whetl~er the order of tlie tides is from higher high to lower low, or from lower low to higher high, the moon being far fro111 the equator. (bl) The ratio of the semime~lsualheight inequality to the mean range of tide; that is, , (Sg - Np)/2 Mn. (cl) The for111of the lunar seinidiurnsl wave. The quantities here selected for determining this are the durirtion of fall and tho heights of tbe sea referred to high arid low waters expressed in terms of the ineau range; that is, LWI- HWI, and heights of the sea or tide a t various liours before and after high and low water expressed in terms of Mn, wlien the range has its mean value. It will be observed that (a'), (bl), and (cl)are nearly equivalent to (a), (b), and (c), respectively, in fixing the form of the tide wave. Whenever the quantities in (a'), (bl), and (cl) are equal a t two stations tho tides are comparable throughout. If only high and low waters are to be com-

+

-

-

-

+

175

176

UNITED STATES COAST rLND GEODETIO SURVEY.

or LWQ/Mn pared, the quantities in (cl) need not to be alike a t both stations unless H W Q / M ~ is a comparatively large quantity; in which case the form of the lunar eemidiurnal wave should be approxi~nately the same :it both stations. A t stations where tlle tide is usllally diurnal the height illequalities are not easily determined. The form of tide rnay be deterlniued from the duration of tho (great) tropic range, together with the rise of tropic H H W and tho fit11 of tropic LLW reckoned from mean sea level. The amount of rise compared with the amount of fall sliows whether E W Q $ LWQ. 52. The sequence of the tides is deterrniued by the following rule : If the H W phase, i. e. 4 (M20- K1O- OI0),lie in the first or third quadrant, higher high precedes lower low; if in the second or fourth quadrant, higher high follows lower low. If twice the H W phase is used, it will lie in the first or secoud selnicircle according as higher high precedes or follows lower low. Having found that the tides a t two stations are comparable, the next step is to givo rules for referring the one to the other. The 1beigibts.-If the planes of reference a t the two stations have the same definition with respect to tho tide, corresponding heights a t the two stations differ only by a constant factor. This factor is usually taken as the ratio of the mean ranges. Where evanescent tides frequently occur, the ratio of the (great) tropic ranges or of tho great diurnal ranges, should be used instead. If the planes of reference have different definitions a t the two stations, the heights a t one of the stations must bo properly reduced before applying the factor. When the tide a t a subordinate station is similar to the one a t the principal station inverted,

Tide predictor No. 1.-This predictor, designed by Thomson, was constructed in about 1876. I t colitiins ten components arrd is described in Thomson and Tait's Natural Philosophy, Part I. I t differs from NOR. 2 and 3 in tlre number of componeuts represented aud iu having cranks carrying pulleys instead of pins working in slots. This machine is now kept a t the South Kensington Museum. Tide predictor hTo. 2.-Tliis machine was designed by Mr. E. Itoberts and is now worked under his direction in preparirrg the " Tide tables for Indian ports." Tlle number of componeuts is twenty. Tide predictor No. 3.-This predictor, designed by Thomson, differs from No. 2 in the number of co~nponents, which is fifteell or sixtee11 instead of twenty, and in tlie direct character of the gearing. It was constructed in about 1SS1. Ge1tera.1 description.-Upoil one or niore shafts, driven by hand or by cloclr\rork, are fixed a number of wlieelv whicl~ mesh into other wheels, causing tlie latter (or wheels nroved by them) to revolve witli ;ingular velocities having g i \ ~ e ratios ~i to tho allgular velocities of the shafts. These ratios are taken, as nearly as possible, proportional to tlie speeds of particular tidal componellts. Rigidly connected to these wheels are cranks carrying pulleys, or pins working in slots, impa,rting to rods carrying pnlloys rectilinoal harmoriic motions. A t oire elid of the predictor a chain or flexible wire is made fast; thence it is laid alternately over aird under tho pulleys. To tJio free end of the wire is attached a markilig point, which when lnoved transversely to tho line of nrotiou of tho paper roll traces the tidal curve. This machine evidently sums tho series (213) or traces the curve (214). 58. Na.xima a)td minima tide-predicting machine. This machine, desigrled by the late Prof. VITilliam Ferrel, of the United States Coast and Geodetic Survey, was constructed in the years 1881-88. A description io given in the lteport for 1883, pages 253-378. Most of the predictions published by tlio Survey since 1885 have been made amplitude of tlie principal lunar upon it. The ni:tchino provides for llineteon componouts. T l ~ e component is introduced into the predictor by sliortening ono of the sulnmation chains about to be mentioned. Its argumeirt is indicated by a hand on the face of the machine making two revolutions for each lunar day. Generally spoalting, the speed ratios in tlie machine are not thoso of the colnpone~lts themselves, but are tlru differences between sucll ratios and the speod ratio of the principal lunar component. The srnaller short-period components are each provided with two cranks fixed a t riglit angles to each other, one for cosir~e terms and one for sille tarme. Each set of cranks carries pulleys, and the resultant eEects are obtained by means of two summation chains. One chaiu is mado to impart s vertical motion to a slotted horizontal strip of steel, while the other imparts a horizontal motion to a slotted vertical strip. These slots intersect a t the center of the machine when all short-period components are set a t zero amplitude. I n general, two settings of the ~nacl~ine are required, one for times and one for heights. When set for times, the direction of tlie intersection of the slots from the center of the machine shows (by aid of an oscillating needle) how the lunar hand must be directed a t the time of a high or low water. When set for heights tho distance of the intersection from the centari is, when multiplied by the cosiue of the angle between the lunar hand and the oscillating needle,$ the elevation or doprbssion of tho sea or tido frorn mean sea level. Tho machine gives tlie times of high and low wator directly; no tidal curve is traced, nor is any comput~tiou required. Approximate values of the heights are also given directly, but the determination of their exact values or of tlre height of tlie sea a t ally intermediate time requires a little additional labor, viz., the setting and reading of an extensible cosine scale. 59. The marking upon the axis of tlie curve the times of the nlaxima and minima.

( 2 ) Now let tliere be a set of cranks a t riglit angles to tlie set used in producing the title curve; for distinction the former may be called the time cranks and the latter height cranlis. Each set lias its resultant effect shown by the movement of the free end (or of a mark a constant distance therefrom) of a wire or slender chain. In each case the result might be sliown in tllo form of a contirruous curve. This, however, is not ordinarily wanted in t,he case of the time cranks. A projeotion upon the wire uniting their etfects comes illto contact with a pencil placed a t mean sea level, causing a short mark to be made every time high or low water occurs. (3) A mark on tlie wire a t a fixed distance from the projection just referred to pilsses before an opening in tlie face of the machine, and is so adjusted that when i t crosses a given line or mark tlle time sliown on the face is the time of high or low water according to the direction of the mire's movement. (4) The heights may be conveniently shown by mealis of ;L p o i ~ ~ t e moving r along a circular row of figures outside the tirile dial. A (il<hPIIIC METHOD O F PREDICTING TIDES 12R03f nARlMONIC CONSTAKTS.

61. The prediction of tides, a s already stated, iinplies tlie combining of a series of waves i ~ r t o dne for the purpose of ascertuinirlg tlie lieight of the tide a,t a give11 tirne or of d e t c r ~ u i ~ i i ltlic ~g tilncs and heiglits of liigii and lorn water. 'rho computation of these qu:~ritities,mliile not difficult, is estrct~lely laborious; ou this account mechaniqal tide predictors have bee11 conatrnctetl. As these ilistrumunts are too ospcnsivo for general uso, a metliod is here proposed whereby predictions miby be made, witliout comput;ltion, fro111 tlie constants used ill settilig a ~nachine-in other words, from the harmonic tidal constants, tho initial equilibrium arguments, and certain factors ( f o f Tablo 10). The apparatus consists, first, of a sinooth board (about 3 by 4 feet), one section of mhicll is divided into twenty-fbur equal spaces, representing tho hours of the day; second, of a sot of pairs of movable curves, drawn once for a11 for a giver1 station, each pair provided with a "cale~idnr?) good for :ill ststiorls and all tilnu; a ~ i d third, of two stationary cleats for holding t h e curves in place, arid : L ~ l u l ~ l b of e r movablo cleats for i~itlices-one for each pair of curves. 62. (239) a t the time t = 0, The above equation assumes that one has the valilc of the initla1 nrgu~nents local time, midnight, say. In practice i t is convenient to take the origin of time a t the instant of midnight 011 a certain standard time meridian, S, and to have the iuitial arguments made out for the n~eridian of Greenwich; then one might alter the arguments in such a may as to adapt them to the longitude of the locality, L, and to the standard time midnight. But if, instead of altering the Greenwich arguments, one alter the epochs by the same amounts, with opposite signs, thc same results will be attained and with the great advantage of being done once for all. Conrrtruction o f a time curve.-The equation of the derived curve corresponding to (241) is

I t will be noticed that the descending ascending nodes of the derived curve will coincide in time with the maxima of the height curve. This is of course equally true for each clement or component of minima the curve. I n ascertaining the magnitude of the coe8Bcients A1al, 2 A, a,, 3 A, a, relative to i t is usually convenient to take the speed of Mza8 unity, expressing other A,, Az, A3, speeds in term of this unit. The derived curvo is used in ascertaining the times of tide, and is drawn in a broken line upon the movable strip upon which the height curve has already been drawn. Construction o f a "calendar."-It will now be supposed that arg, Ap ie given for only one day of each year, January 1. The change in the given arg, A, necessary to adapt i t to any other

. . . ,

. . .

RXPOBT FOB 1 8 9 A P A R T 11.

18.3

d;ty of the yoar may be assumed to be uniform, and tho same for all years. This change is introduced by means of a Lccalendar peculiar to the component and its harmonics. Anywhere a t tho left of the curves, a soction of the strip one period in length is set apart for the days of the year. The positious of the datov are given by Table 4. Jauuary 1 will be located a t the right or left edgo of the period according as the speed of the component is less or greater than that of the solar component of approximately the same speed. It is sornotirnes more convenient to set apart two or more periods for the calendar. This will necessitate two or more blank periods of the curve, instead of one, before the period used in laying down arg, A,. This means, of course, an increase in the length of the curve. Lunar nodal components, etc.-In order to avoid numerous smell components, especially those dependent upon the longitude of the moon's node, the lunar tides are made to undergo small changes in argument which are not directly proportional to tlle time, and also small cha~iges of amplitude. The former have bee11 :iccountecl fbr in Tablo 3 by the u of V,, u,or arg,, where u llns an irregular variation, but so slow that for the purpose of prediction it may bo regarded as constaut during a year. The variations of amplitude aro givorl by the f 7 s of Table 10, and can be sllown upon the curves by me:tris of a scale of proportional parts of the mean values of the anlplitude anti ordinates of each component. But as tliof's vary quite uniforrnly with I (the inclination of the lunar orbit to to mark upon certain ordinates of the curve the equator, Tables 1anci 13) it is generally sufiicie~it their increased or decreased values corresponding to changes in I. The time scale.-This scalo consists of twenty-five equidistant lines driiwn upon the statiouary board underneath all of tho curves. Tile strips up011which tho curves are drawn should be separated from one another by liarrow spaces, so that the time scale, or rather the hour lines, may be aeon between them. 64. Directions for predicting. Find in Table 3 the value of V,, + u of each component for the givon year and bring this number of the degree scalo over tho zero hour line. Set tho vibrious indices over tho date J a w ary 1. For any other day move the scales until tho indices, as already set, come over the required date upon each scale. Suppose, in the first instance, that the height of tho sea or tido is required a t any particular hour of this day. Alol~g tlio edge of a pioce of papor mado hcoincide with the given hour line,mark the positive ordinates of the full curvAs (slightly modified to account for the varying obliquity of the noon's orbit to the equator) 80 that a11 such ordinates shall be added together. Alo~ig the same edge, but on the opposite surface of the paper, mark tho negative ordinates, beginning a t tho heiglit upon tho paper slip reached by tho positivo ordinates and going in an opposite direction. Tho resulting difference is the height of tho tide above or below mean aea love1 a t the stated hour. If a lower plane of reference bo preferred, its depression below mean sea level should be laid off upon the paper slip beforo marking tho ordinates up011 it. To $nd the time o f high or lozo ?cater.--By glancing a t the dotted curves of the principal comporients one can usually tell roughly whero the algebraic sum of their ordiuates approach select a desconding node; if a low wator, an aucendil~g. zero. If a high water timo is sougl~t, A t two adjacent hours near the high or low wator, lay ott'upon a slip of paper the positive and negative ordinates of the dotted curves, properly modified for the varying obliquity of the moon's orbit to the equator. . Now take any scale about three hours in length, divided to single minutes. From this lay off e tlie two the two resulting heights, olio liour apart. A straightedge will show where a l i ~ i joining points just laid down will cut the tinlo scale. The time thus determined is the time of high or low water with reference to either hour line. 65. It i~ obvious that the foregoing method is applicable to periodic phenomena, altliough the constituent periodic curves may have no reaenlblauco to simple c o s i ~ ~ curves. e Such curvos are constructed by means of conlponent hourly ordinates obtained fiaonl t,he observations. These remarks have special referonce to the prediction of tidal currents.

UNITED STATES COAST AND GEODETIO SURVEY.

66. By means of the following method predictions can be made without resorting to graphic processes, and without access to a tide-predicting machine. Jloon's transits, phases, etc.-If the tralisits used are for the meridiax~of Greenwich (E)a.nd expressed in civil time, they may be adapted to another meridian (L) aiitl exl~ressed in stand;u.d or prediction time ( 8 ) by adding rJ - S+O.OSS ( L - IT) (246)

g 27. The times of the moon's phases, distances, and declinations :we expressed in sta~ldard time by adding E-S
to their Greenwich civil times. A further illcrease of r hours, tho age of the particular inequality, gives the standard or prediction time of the conspiring or interfering to which the inequality is due. See sheet headed " Ephclneris." The tidal constants.-The consta~lts are as follows:

A, is the mean amplitude of the tide with the effects of the diurnal compoue~~ts excluded. is the modified form of K,o, defined in 5 62. H W I and LWI are so taken that their sum is zero, as nearly as possible. A,, M2, S,, N,, K1, 0, are reduced to their values for the year of the l~redictions by the factors f'(M2),f (M,), 1,f (M,), f (KI), f (O,),respectively, found in Tablo 10. 67. The "Ephemeris" and the sheet following it indicate the work preparatory to making predictions. The process of prediction indicated below consists of three steps, the deterrninstion of the semidiurnal wave,of the diurnal, and of combining the two thus determined. Port Townseud, Washmgton, is taken as an illustration because of its large diurnal components.

2.?d?!

If r denote the speed of any given component C, then a component whose speed is

has with C a synodic period n hours in length. If C be the principal one of the two components, then the effect of the other is to introduce an inequality into Cof a period equal to n. The known motions of the moon and sun suggest what tidal inequali ties may exist corresponding to periodic irregularities in the motions of these bodies, or in the motions of the elements of their orbits. The following tabulation shows that it is often necessary to use more than one component to account for what may be regarded as an irregularity in the principal component :

NOTBS OH SOME INsTRUME!NTS RECENTLY MADE IN THE INSTRUMENT DIVISION O F THE OOAST AND GEODETIC SURVEY OFFICE.

The instrument sliop i~ I\, repttir and experimental shop, and the construction of 1iew inst,rumerits is iricidental to this work, being mostly confilled to such instrument8 as lnay be required

for e s l ) c r i ~ i i e or ~ ~ inay t be suggested by the experience of the field parties, tlie cor~struction of wl~icliinvolves a coiividernble slnolil1t of experimental work nnd persoi~al supervision. Sl~ch i~istruir~ents are ofteu evolutions and their construction would not be u~ldertnkenby private or co~umercial sliops except a t n 111uch greeter cost to the Survoy. In order to secure the best results, the Superintendent, in October, 1890, appointed :In advisory board 011 instruinelits arid their construct~on, con~isting of tlie following officers: Assistants C. A. Schott, R. 5 . Woodward, 0. H. Tittmann, Audrem Braid, Edwin Smith, E. I). I'reston, and tl~c chief instrume~itmaker, Mr. E. G . Fischer. The Chief of tho Instrulneut Division acted : l s chsirman. Since that date all i~liportantmatters referring to instruments l ~ a v e been considercbd by this board, :wd as reg:br(ls new instruments its e i n ~ has been to make them as perfect as possible, taking advantage of tlie experience of all surveys in this as well as foreign countries. The Survey is f o r t u ~ ~ i~ n t having a a ~rcll-equippedshop and several excellent i i i s t r u ~ n e ~ ~ t mslrera. To the chief instr~iri~e~it milker especial credit is due for excellent deagns and mtitly valuable rnechanicd suggestions. The iiistruments briefly described in this paper are some that have been co~~stl-ucted sii1c.o 1890. Descriptions of others will be found in other reports, the pendulurna iu report of 1891, the Holton base apparatus in report of 1892, etc.
TWO 30'5"" (12-INCH) POSITION THEODOLITES, NOS. 145 AND 146, MADE IN THE INSTRUMENT DIVISION OF THE COAST AND GEODETIC SURVBY OFFICE, 1890-1893. SEE PLATE I.

These numl>ers(145 arid 146) belonged to two theodolites that had been in the poseession of the Survey for several years, but had not proved sa.tisfactory. An attempt was made to remodel them As the work progressed various difficulties were enconntered, nnd the result was the construction of two instruments entirely new except tlie circles. The two old circles had been cast fro111differe~ll p:itterns,'aiid when they had been turi~etlow, regribdunted, and mounted upon tlle instrnments, i t wsv di~coveredthaG the circle of No. 146 mas weak n,nd had sprurtg when twliott off the cllucli. I t mas quit,e as perfect as Inany itom ill u80 niid the defect was not thorigllt to be
'

L'C6

UNITED STASES COAST AND GEODETIC SUBVEY. serious-in fact, would not have been noticed but for the unusually high power of the micrometer Beforo the instrument was sent to tlie field a new circle similar to tlie one on No. ~nicroscop~s. 145 was ~ilade fbr it. The two ilistrulnents are now as nearly alike as it is practicable to make tlleln. Thc followi~lg description will apply to both: The base is of cast iron, into the socliet of mliich is fitted another cast-iron socket, to wl~icll is rigidly attached the brass circle ant1 illto which is fitted the center which carries the alidade. Under the circle is a devico for firmly clamping 'this socket to the base in any position of tlie circle. The, center is 22.2cm (8 inches) long, its two beariug surfaces being cones of diffbrent angles. I t is made of the best quality of tool steel, and the cones are made glass hard. No pains were sl)arecl in tho constructior~ of these centers and sockets, and i t is believed they are tho most perfect ever made for theodolites, and are probably the first theodolite centers with glass-ha.rd bearirig surfaces. In the alidade the cover of the circle, the supports for the micrometer microscopes, the wye supports, axis, and setting circle of telescope are made of aluminurn. The bearing surfaces of the wyes are of brass, and the pivots of telescope axis are of bell metal. The draw tube of telescope, micrometer microscopes, clalnps, :uiti other small parts are of brass. Tlie use of slurninurn in the constructio~lof these itistruments was not with tlie special pnrpose of reducing the total weight of the instrument, but to reduce the weight supported upon the centers. The cast-iron bases of these instrumeuts, in proportiori to the wliole mass of tlie instruments, are niuch heavier than is usual ill other theodolites of the same size. These heavy bases and long centers give great stability to the instruments. The weight of the wl~ole alidade is 7.6 kilogramnies (17 pounds), whereasin other instruments of the same size that have been used in tlie Survey the weight, of similar parts is 18 kilogrammes (40 pounds). The centers of tlie oltl instruments are of various forms, and the frictiori is so great tliat it has to be relieved by some device a t lower elid of centers. No such device is necessary with the new instrumellts. The total weight of one of the new irlstrunlents is 18.5 kilograrnmes (41 pounds). The telescope objective was made by J. Brashear, and ifi (i.lctl1 (2.4 inches) aperture, and 73.'icm (29 inches) focus. The telescope has a11 ocular micrometer, with three Ramsden eyepieces, givilig powers of 30,45, ;md 60. Several levels, all made by A. Pesseler, of Germany, are attached to tho alidade for convenience. The stride level has divicrior~s of 2mn1, wit% arc value of 4". The graduation. of the circle is on coin silver and is 30.5cn1(12 inches) in diameter. It is divided to 5' and reads to seconds by three equidistant micronleter microscopes. Each degree of the graduation is numbered. The degrees and w lea rest 5 / are read by a low-power index microscope 500 to the right of micrometer microscope A. Attached to the cover of the circle is a small camel'shair brusli which sweeps over the graduation. The circles mere graduated 011 the United States Coast and Geodetic Survey engine. This graduating engino was originally mado by Troughton Sr; Simms, of Londou, and bears the date of 1841. In the hands of the Survey i t has received v a r i o ~ ~ improvements, s the chief of which are a new tracing apparatus and new support for the same. The engine is driven by a small turbine wheel uporl which a constant water pressure is maintained. To graduate a circle to 5' takes about 3" 3.7". The graduations are made a t a temperature of 36o.GG 0.(980 F.),that temperature being most easily maintained a t any season of tlie year and least affected by the occasional presence of the operator. For tlie last nine yea,rs this engine has been manipulated exclusively by tho present chief instrument inaker of the Survey and in his harids has produced some very fine gradu;ttions, as the results with the two new theodolites, Nos. 145 and 146, s11ow. I n April and May of 1893 a critical examination of these tlleodolites mas made by Assistant It. S. Woodward under iristruction from the Superintendent of the Survey. He has submitted orlly a preliminary report, from which the following is taken: "This examination has special reference to the perfection of the horizontal circles of the instruments, and was conducted in accordance with the following plan submitted to you in Iny letter of March 31, 1893. It is here restated as there given, in order that the l i n e along which the inquiry proceeded may be clea,rly apparent. (1) In order to determillo the value of a space on the horizontal circle, which space may be used as a standard space, it will be essential to compare ~ u c h space with a large number of other &pacessituated a t equidistant intervals about the circle. The a,verage value of this large number

REPORT FOR 1894--PART 11.

267

of sl)ac:ea luny be assurned to be the nominal value, wlierice the standard space will become kno~vn,. ;~nd it niay tlier~be used for determining error of runs of micrometers. This process will also give tlie errors of all Sl)aCeR observed, and thus afford a good general test of the equality of the spaces. (2) We Inay then pass to an cxa~ninntionof tho inequality of the arcs covered by the dist:t~lcobetween consecutive ~iiicroscopes. By observirig tl~eseinequalities for a large number of i11.c~ sy~lnmetrically disposed about t l ~ u entire c~rcle the harmonic series expressing the divergelice ti,r :uiy :~rc may be computed. A cornparison of the computed and observed values of such divergencies will reveal any consitlerable accidental errors. L L (3) 13y far the most important class of errors affecting circles of yrecisiori are the periodic in the sun1 (or.meau) of the equidistant lilicroscopo readings. These errors errors not climi~iated atfect measured'angles, while the periodic errors mentioned under (2) above do not. To determine tile harhonic expression for this unore important class of errors tlie best metllod appears to be to observe as carefully as practicable a series of angles which will produce the lnavimum eflect, respectively, from the several torms ot' tlie series. Sucli nleasures mill euable us tr, coulpute the a~i~plitucle~ :i11(1 the phase angles of tlie several harmonic ternis, and thus give ;i formula for tlie correctio~i to ally measured angle, whatever its size and whatever the part of tho circle on which i t may bo observed. ;LUefbro giving an abstract of the results of the examination it appears proper to mske solno st;~teu~ents with reference to the general fo:itures of t8hesei~istrumeuts and the degree of mechanic;~l~)el.fection shown by them. Having ex:imiricd amnuniber of eimilar itlstrumerits made by Troiiglito~i & Simms, the ltepsolds, Pistor 6 :Martins, and Fantli & Co., it has bee11 easy to judge of tlio relative merite of tlio new t~lieotlolites. f i With respect to design slid perfection of mechanical construction, these riew theodolites must, I tl~ink, take rar~lr ~ r i t , tlio l ~ liigliest of tlioir class. In equality of spacing of consecutive gradu:ttion lines and in t l ~ uniformity c of width and aspect of tl~ese li~les the circles of the instruments appear to be superior to :ill circles I havo exarililled under an equal magnifying power. '6 Witli respect to their capacity for rr~easuri~ig horizontal angles, repeated trials show that they are a t Icnst equal to tlie best iustruments made elsewhere. It appears, in fact, that, so far 2 1 s purely instrume~ital and observationi~l errors are co~~cerued, a mean measured anglo from four equidiutaut positioris of tlie circle of either instru~lieut will havo a precision equal to the requirements of the highest order of primary triangulation. "Concerning the lightness of the instruments, whicli is a nov.el feature, i t appears to me quite satisfactory. Without assistance an observer can tali0 oiie of them from its case aricl p1;~ce it on a pier or stand with perfect safety; arid this is often a matter of ocoriolny and great convonie~ice. On tho other hand, the small niass of tho ilivtrun~entsmay not be satisfactory to some observers. After usirlg heavier instruments of tlie same class (like those made by Troughton & Simms, for example) ale's Arst improssion is that tho new theodolitos are lacking in rigidity. This is lnost ~~oticeable ill the micrometer arms, whicli are quito se~isitive to lateral stress. I t does riot appear, however, that this lwlc of rigidity cau bo sensibly detrimental, especially wit11 observers who understand their work. If any disadvantage result therefrom, it is, in my opinion, more thall offset by the advanta,ge coming from the lightness. "There is ono noticeable defect of theodolite No. 146. I t lies in dep,axtures of the graduakd surface of its circle from a conical sui.f~ce. These departures, though small, are large enough to require diflerent focal adjustmonts of the particular microscope used 011 diflere~itparts of the circle in order to secure satisfactory freedom from parallax. Nevertheless, when the microsco~)es are adjusted for the average distauce of the circle from them, tlie ed'ect of parallax does rlot appear to be sensible in measured angles. The defect manifests itself then only by iudistiuct visiou on sorne parts of the circle. " IVitli respect to tlie clamp and tangent for the alidado and tho movement of the latter about its axis, the performance of the instrulnerit is very satisfactory. Tho great length of the :didado axis undoubtedly givos precision and stability to the motion of tlie microscopes. The projectio~iof the socket of this axis below tho plane of the foot screws would be courited an objoctiori by some, but if a real objection i t appears to be of little weight.

Spacing of consecutive graduation marks.-In accordauce with sectiou (1)of tlie plan outli~red a.bove, a largo number of spaces were measured by means of the micrometers on each circle. Tlle results have been compnted for theodolite No. 146 only; and i t may be doubted wl~etl~er those for No. 146 are pi-operly trustworthy, since they involve errors due to parallax which may equal or ever1 aurpass those of spacing. The observations on the spacing of No. 145 were ~uatie by Assista ~ l Sinclair. t Each space of a group of equidistant spaces on the circle' was measured with the lnicronleter fonr times independently; and a t intervals during the measures of these spaces several similar determinations mere made of the assumed standard space. This latter is the space 50005l fo 600101. The data thus obtained give the latter space in t e r ~ n of s tho average value of all the spaces of the group. Four such groups ot measures were made. Tlie results are given in the tables below. The position of any space is defined by tho index reading of n~icroscope A, with which the measures mere made. In all cases the space referred to is that between the 5/ and 10' marks, these being chose11because they are of tho same length and thus present the same aspect to the observer.

"Thus it appears that the average error of spacing of the spaces examined is 0.20 div., or but 0.16 microns. This indicates a degree of precision in spacing of a very high order. In this respect the graduation must be regarded as practically perfect. Attention may be called to tlie progressive iricrease in the Rums of the measured spaces when taken by quadrants or by semicircles. This is quite large in the ca;se of the observations of April 5, but tlie subseqnent observations are less consistent on this point.

L b Inequulity o f arcs comprised between consecutive microscopes.-Sevoral series of measures of the distar~cebetween a pair of microscopes wore made on the oquidist;tnt arcs with excl~instrument. Tlie followiirg results will suflice to show what is tlevoloped by this test. Suppose A and B denote the readings of tlie ~nicroscopes1i:wing tho same designatiol~011 any part of the circle; the difference, (B-,A) will involve the escess of t,he distance betmeell these microscopes over the nominal distance, or 1200. Call this excess a. Then if (B- A ) be observed 011 a large nun~bel: of arcs a t equal intervals about the circle, i t may be shown that a. is tlio mean of the differences ( B - A ) so ob~erved. The table gives the values of (R- A ) -a for interval^ of 100 for each instrument.

b L Thoso inequalities show n range of about 15". They are fairly regular, however, uud n~ill uudonbtedly bevory closely rcpresentecl by two or three harmonic teniis when these nro co~nputed. 66 Tllo incautious reader shoulcl be warned :tgainst tlie coitrmoii error of snpyosing that sucli lneqoalities are necessarily due to eccentricity of tho alidade with respect to tile circle. Ono call only say that these ineqllalities are the resultarlt of all sourcos of error, i~icludi~lg eccentricity, tlicmselves in tlie digeronco of :I pair of rnicrosoopo readiiigs. In general tlie which ~liai~ifest cornl)onents of this resultant are numerous, but riot separately deter~llii~;tble. I\foreover, these inequalities :ire rclatively unimportsnt. So tar as thoy are pui.ely periodic they shed no light on that class ~vllicli:~ffectsthe suin or mean of the ~nicroscopereadilrgs, which is tlio only really importaut class of errors mitli which me 1i:bvo to deal. I t should not bo iuferred, therefore, that tlle circles of tlieso theodolites are defuctivo. Tho comnloii uotion that such illequalities constitute defects is not founded on adequate knowledge. ( 6 Iiesults for measz~red a,tgles.-I11 order to test the instruments in the actual work of mensuring angles, a temporary observatory was set up on Meridian Hill, ~vliere a clear view of a good share of tho llorizori could be had. A heavy stone pier was set firmly in tho ground, and on this was placed a capstoile fitted to receive tho theodolites. The capstone was cemel~ted to the pier : i d the footplates to the capstono with Portland cemeut. Thus :~rrti~~gecl the foundatio~i for the iristruments wits very rigid. About the pier was built a platform, on n.hlch an ordinary station tent was placed to protect tho instrurne~it fro111 wind and the ordinary rays of the sun. Tho following tabular stttte~~~olit gives the results obtained. A result for an angle is here talren to be the Incan of two measures mitile, the 0110 by turuing the r~liditde i l l the tlirection of the graduation, aud the other by turning in the opposito direction iilimediately afterward. This is done to eliminate twist of the i~lstrurnentand its sapl)ort. Solno observatio~~s ~uadowith No. 146 ~ho\ved a twist of 0".3 due to turning the iilidado t111.ongl1 3Gk. b L Tile nlagi~ifyiligpower used in tJio telescol)e mas aborlt GO diameters (tho ~~leasured valuc for No. 146 was 57.6).

UNITED STATES. COAST AND GEODETIC SUZLVEY. "Direct observations with No. 146 showed a probable error of a ~ i n g l e pointing fo be ~LO'l.25. This is tlle resultant of the error of fixing the telescope ou the object and the error in the mean of the three microscope readiugs. L L The results are arranged i n groups of four each with reference to the positions of the circle, these being auch a s to give tilo best elirnhation of tho circle errors iu the mean of the four v a h e s of a group. Tlie accordance of these means for the different groups is the point to which atteution should be directed. The individual results of any group may,'and should, in general, differ from one another; but if tlio graduation of the circle is good, the group means should show small ranges.

"Oonsidering the above group means as so many measures of the several angles to which they refer, respectively, i t appears that the probable error of one such mean, or the probable error of the mean angle from four positions of the circlo, is 4OU.28. This error is the resultant of all sources of error which affect such measures, namely, periodic and accidental errors of graduation, errors of observation, errors due to unstaadiness of the atmosphere (which was riot exc:eptionally favorable during the period covered by the observations), etc. It is evident, therefore, that the periodic and accidental errors not eliminated in the mean result fro111 four positions of the circle are very small. "The range amongst the individual measures of a n o u p risos at most to 6", and sillce the angles measured were selectad with a view t o developing this range, i t is probable that this represents tho maximum range, due to periodic errors, which one may expect to find in augles measured with these instruments. "The results of this test are, tllen, very favorable to the instruments and show that they are fully oqual in their capacity to the best instruments hitherto mado." After the new circle mas made for No. 146 there was no time for a critical examination of i t before it was sent to the field. A partial examination made in the Instrument Division brought out the same characteristics as were found by Assistant Woodward for No. 145. The two instruments were sent to the field in the summer of the present year (1894). No. 145 was used a t station Bison by Assistant F. W. Perkinu and No. 146 a t ,Mount Elbert by Assistant P. A. Welker. These tat ions are i t 1 the main transcontinental triangulation in the Rocky Mountains. Mount Bison is 3,749 metres (12,300 feet) and Mount Elbort is 4,389 metres (14,400 feet) above sea level. The following results are from the field records:

This method of observing was adopted in order to detect auy flexure or disturbslice of the instrument in turniug the alidade from left to right and back from right to left. The detailed results do not show eitlier flexure or disturbance of instrument. The iridividual results in the tablo depend upon a t least eight pointings on each sigual, and the angle between each sigllal and the mark is ~neasured by six symmetrical arcs on the circle. The ~~esultiug meau of each group of on eacli signal, and the angle between four positions depends upon a t least thirty-two poil~titigs e,wh signal and the mark is measured by twenty-four symmetrical arcs on tlte circle. The firlal means depend upon a t least one hundred :uld twenty-eight pointings on each sigu:il, and the angles are measured by ninety-six symmetrical arcs 011 the circle. Tllc probable error of au angle from the mark from thc rncall of a group of four positious is 4- 0".18 and frorn the mean of tho four groups of four positions is 4 0"-08. Tlie grcatest deviatton of any individual result in the table from the lneall of the sixteen positions is l'I.93 ill Positiou IV, angle 4 . A t this station the sigrtals were distant as follows: Pikes Peak, 59 kilometres (36.0 ~niles); Ouray, 110.5 kilonietres (G8.J miles); Elbert, 83 kilolnetrea (514 ~niles), and Divide, 87 kilometres (54.1 miles). These s~guals were heliotropes. The dlstance attd description of msrk is not given, but was probably a paiuted board :&bout3 ltilotnetres, or 2 ~nilcs, distant. This practical field test of these iustrunients is liighly satisfactory and shows that with them a very much smaller llumbcr of positions aud pointiugs will meet the requirements of the highest class of prim;iry triaugulatiol~. Tlie results a t AIonnt Elbert with No. 146 are not given, but are reported to be satisfactory. Before the observations mere finished theodolite No. 146 was twlce struck by lightning. The ob.jective of the telescope was seriously injured and tlie pivots of telescope, bearings of wyes and leveli~lg screws burned. The irlstrument seems tc) have sustairied 110 other injury. I t was repaired as well as possible in the field and the observations completed. I t has sincc been tllrough the instrument sllol) of the office, :t new objective was furnished, and the whole iustrument put in good order again.
A 20.3cul (8-INC'II) POSI'CION THEODOLITE REMODELISD IN T H E INS'CRUMENT DIVISION O F 'I'IIE UNITED STATES COAST AND GEODETIC SIJRVJCY OFFICE, 1891. S E E PLATE 11.

The remodeling of this theodolite wss so thorougl~that it is practically a new instrument. m:ule: The following are tho cl~aliges New double cone ce~iter of hardened steel and cafst-iroil socket. Sew rniorotneter screws and eyepieces to the micrometer ~nicroscopes. Circle regraduated aud every degree numbered. Circle firmly attached to ceuter and device added for .illifting positiou of circle i~t1(1 (:ellt(:r. Cover to circle added. New eyepieces to telescope. General repairs. The center is 14.7cm(5.8 inches) lolig and projects above the circle. I t is clamped to the base in any position of the circle by meaus of the wheel nut shown in the illustration. The socket carries the alidade. The only alnrninum used in this instrument is the cover to the circle. The diameter of the graduation is 20.3Cn1(8 inches). It is divided to 10' and read to 211 by two micrometer microscopes. The heads of the micrometers are divided into 60 part&and numbered as follows: 0, 10, 20, 0, 10, 20. One revolution of the screw is 2/, and oue division of tlie head is 311. I n the micrometer, in place of the usual rack, is a glass scale, 10 parts of which correspond to a space of 10' on the circle and to 5 revolutions of the micrometer screw. The micrometar slide carries double wires. The micrometer reads 0 when the right-hand wire of double wires is on middle line of glass scale and the head of screw is a t 0. Degrees end minutes are read directly in the microscope. The readings of tho micrometer heads should be recorded as divisions. The

ltEPORT FOR 1894--PART 11. sum of the readings of the two lnicro~noterheads will give the mean reading of tlie two microscopes in seconds. The tolescope objective has a clear a,perture of 4~45~"' (1.76 inches) and a focal length of 40.64Cn1 (16 inches). Three BamSden eyepieces give powers of lG, 24, and 32. The levels are by Pessler, of Germany. The stride level 11:~sdivisious of 2111111, with arc valiie are uow being remodeled in the lnstru~nent Division. of about 411-6. Three more sucll instru~ne~its

111 their general form these instruments are similar to those that haw70 been in use in the Survey for solue years, an illustration of which will be found in United States Coast and Geotletic Survey Report for 1881, Appeudix No. 8, plate 36. This form of mag~~etolueter is now so well known that a detailed description is here unnecessary. The new instru~iients are a little larger than the old upon them in details of design and especially in stability anti perfection ones and are i~nprovements of workmanship. The new collirn~ting maguets are octagor~al in form. The stirrups in which tllc lnagnets are suspendotl are very Liglit aud made to support the maguets on two of their plane surfaces. The nagn nets can be suspeuded in the stirrups with scales accurately vertical, either erect or inverted a t once, and the inertiit ring can be accnrately balanced upoil the ~uaguet with equal facility. Witli the old cylindrical magnets tllese operations were ditlicult and very tryiug to the patience of the observer. By uieausof :I small rot1 i~ttaclied to the stirrup tho point a t which the suspension distance above tlie ce~iterof the magnet. The effect flber is fastened is raised a co~lsiderable of dip in diflerent localities to displace the 111agnetfrom its horizontal position is thns overcohe and the sliding ring used in the old instru~nentsis unnecessary in these uew ones. The oscilits ruoruent of inertia also. Another new feature lating mass is always the same and conseque~ltly is the black velvet screen counecting the telescope wit11 the suspeusion box. This does away with the glass window usually placed in the suspension box between t l ~ etelescope objective and'the objective of the magnet. I t also cuts off all stray light butween the telescope arid the magnet and renders the illumination of tho magnet scalo a matter of great ease.

This balances the instrument very nicely made as far as practicahle of nhl~ninum, ~ t smade of brass and a& top-heavy. and gives it stability. The older i ~ l s t r u m e ~are (2) Operiings are made in the ruler giving :r tid~lcialedge directly uilder the line of collimatiou of telescope for use ill large scale work. Thero are two arcs that are interchangeable, one with a range of f160 for ordiuary work, and oue wit11 a rarige ot' A300 for mountain work. A P P E N D I X NO. 9-1894.

FORMULA3 AND TABLES POR THE: COMPUTATION O F GEO1)ETIC POSITIONS.
[Fo~lrthedition.]

The first edition of these formulm and tables was published as Appendix No. 36, Coast Survey Report for 1860, under tho titlo u F o r m u l ~tables, , arid oxarnple for the geodetic computation of latitudes, longitudes, and azimuths of trigonometrical points, as used in the United States Coast Survey." Tlie tables were first computed by Assistant Th. W. Werner in 1847, and were used in manuscript form up to 18G0, aud a t later dates tllcy were extended in range of latitude in order of tho Survey. They aro based upon the formula for the computation to satisfy further tie~nands of geodetic positions as developed by l'uissaot, and their derivation will be found in Volume I, Chapter SV,of his Treatise on Geodesy.' These formula, were adapted in 1846 to the use of the Coast Survey by Assistant J. E. Hilgard (superintendent during 1881-85), who added an intermediate term to-tho expression for difference of latitude lo reuder i t more accurate, and provided for the table of factors to facilitate the oomputation of goodetic positions. The spheroid of reference upon the surface of which the triangulations of tho Survey were supposed to be developed was that derived by Bessel and published in the ~stronomischc Nachrichten, No. 438 (December, 1841). The secol~d edition of the tables is contrtinetl in Coast Survey Report for 1875, Appendix No. 10. Tlie derivation of t l ~ u toruiu1:e is there given and the tables are extended froni latitude 500 to latitude 630; it contains, besides, two auxiliary tables to facilitate computations when changing tho reference splieroid from that of Bessul to that of Clarke (1866). However, it was not till February 4,1880, that Superintendent Patterson ordered the substitution of the latter spheroid for t,he Besselian, which latter had been in use on the Survey since the year 1844.t This charlgo necessitated tlio issub of tho third edition ill Coast anti Geodetic Survey Report for 1884, Appendix No. 7. 'rho text was reprinted and the table given in connection with the computation o f the spherical excess appeared extouded ill latitude. The present edition differs from tho preceding one by the introduction of a change in the notation of the formula, substituting for the older form one in better accord with modern custom, and, further, by au extension of the tables so us to take ill the highest latitude of United States territory, bekides 50 added to the former southernmost limit.

The m a t b r is now of little interest, since nll c o m p ~ ~ t n t i oof t~s positio~ts havo l o ~ since g boon repeated.

The linear dimensions of Bessel's spheroid were originally expressed in toises. Their metric equivalents as generally adopted are given below. The dimensions of Clarke's spheroid (of 1866) are stated by him in feet, toises, and metres. (See Appendix to Comparisons of the Standards of Length, etc., by Capt. A. 32. CIarke, under the direction of 001. Sir H. James, etc., London, 1866, page 287.) The dimensions in metres are:

Strictly speaking, the latte; dimensions, to be expressed, as they must be, in terms of the prototype metre, should be slightly changed, for the reason that Clarke's results depend primarily on the yard and the relation of the yard and metre as found by him, 1yard = 0.914 391 80" (or 1 foot = 0.304 797 27"),* should now be changed to conform to the more correct relation,+ viz: 1 foot = 0.304 800 61m, or 1 metre = 3.280 833 3 feet; the diff'erence, however, is unimportant, since either spheroid might have been adopted, and it would be inexpedient to recompute the tables of factors. Among later determinations of spheroids representing the earth% figure, and apart fkom several published by Colonel Clarke, we may mention two of very different derivation, viz: Prof. W. Harkness, U. S. N., in his L L The Solar Parallax and its Related Constants, Washington, D. C., 1891," reached the following result, vie: Xquatorial semidiameter, G 377 972 4 125 metres; a-b1 . - 300.2k3,0; P. Tisserand, in his 6 L Trait6 polar semidiameter, 6 356 727 99 metres, and

--

de Mechanique CBleste, Tome 11, Paris, 1891," states that the aplatissement (flattening) could not provided the earth7sdensity increises continuously from surface o ' center be greater than m 3 and the shape of the surface is due to original fluidity. A new value for this representative figure of the geoid, more reliable than any yet deduced, may be expected to result from the labors of the International Geodetic Association for the measurement of arcs, particularly since arcs of the parallel can no longer be regarded as so far inferior in value to arcs of the meridian as to exclude them from combination with the latter, both however being seriously influenced by local deflections of the vertical. Arc measures in a country, if of sumcient extent, may be utilized for deducing or choosing a special spheroid adapted to its surface, as was, for instance, the case with the Clarke spheroid, which is supposed to conform better to the compact area of the United States than the one previously in use. In what follows, the derivation of the formula and the arrangement for the computation of geodetic positions, as given by Assistant J. E. Hilgard, have been reproduced from the preceding edition, after changing the notation as mentioned above. C. A. SUHOTT, Assistant. DECEXBER, 1894.

FORBIULB AND FACTORS F O R THE COMPUTATION

28 1
LO~GITUDES, AND

O F GEODETIC LATITUDES,

AZIiVlUTHS.

When the geographical coordinates of latitude and longitude of a point on the earth's surface and the distance and azimuth to another point are known, the problem of computing'the latitude and longitude of the second point and the reverse azimuth may be treated in two different ways. We may either solve the spheroidal triangle formed by the two points and the pole, as a whole, arriving a t trigonometricd functions of the required co-latitude, azimuth, anddifference of longitude, or we may develop expressions Ibr the differences of the required and the given quantities. The former or direct method has the inconvenience of requiring the use of ten places of deci. mals in the computation, in order to give the positions with a degree of exactness corresponding to that of the known distance between the two points, while the second leads to very convenient expressions, on account of the smallness of the differential arcs in ordinary triangulation. When, however, the arc between the two points reaches several degrees in length, the direct method must be resorted to. This solution has been very completely and elegantly effected by Beseel, and is given in Astronomische Nachrichten, No. 86,1826. Adopting the second method, we follow in the main Puissant (Trait6 de CBod6sie)* in the development of the difference of latitude of two points on the spheroid in terms of the distance, azimuth, and latitude of the given point. It will be desirable first to recall the expressions of several lilies of an ellipse in terms involving the latitude p which is the angle the normal to any point on the ellipse makes with the major axis. Designating the major or equatorial semi-axis by a a i d the minor or pola,r semi-axis by b then the ellinticity E or the ratio of their difference to the former is

The radius of curvature R and the normal N are principal quantities used in geodesy. I t will be observed that radii of curvature for different latitudes do not intersect unless prodnced, and that when they Lie in d3erent meridional planes on the spheroid they will not intersect a t all.

Fig 2.
A and B in fig. 2 are two points on a spheroid of revolution, having the latitudes 9,cpt, and joined by tho geodetic line AB = 8, making the angles with the meridian PAB = 1800 - a,and PBA = a' - 1800. The azimuths a, a' are reckoned from south around by west in consequence of the latitudes being reckoned, by settled custom, from the equator toward the poles, otherwise the lneridional coordinate of a point would be more properly measured from the pole and the azimuth of a line reckoned from the north. The angle A P B between the two meridional planes passing through A and B is the difference of their longitudes A, hi, which being reckoned positive to the westward we have ht h = Ah. Furthermore, An, Bn', Ar, Br' indicate the normals N,N', and the radii of curvature in the meridian R, R ' ,a t the points A and B. This being premised and the latitude q of the point A being given, as well as the length s of the geodetio line AB and its azimuth a, we propose to and the latitude gr' of the point B, the angle

The inverse problem.-Cases frequently occur where the distance and mutual azimuths are demanded of two points whose latitudes and longitudes orlly are known. It has not been found necessary to prepare special formulx and blank forms for this cornputfation, as i t can readily be ' by made with the help of the preceding forms, It is done by dividing RA = 8 sin a . A sec 9 the first term for Acp, I& = s COB a . B, whence we get

.

tan

rx

Ah. B = A sec y 'h

Thls would give the azimuth a t once, provided we knew h, since dA is given. We therefore compute the smaller terms for the difference of latitude in order to obtain 1~by subtracting them from the known value of dp. The only addition to the usual form is the term log. tan a = log (s sin a ) log (s cos a). The value of 8 will best be taken from the term h when sin a exceeds cos a, end from tlie term Ah when the reverse is the case. When the distance 8 is large, as in primary triangulation, it will be necessary to introduce the correction for dA due to diflerence of ratio between sine and arc, using the form for primary work, inversely, as indicated above.

The additional worlt of triarigulation done in and since tlie year 1885 was for tlie 111ost part confined to tho e:istern ~ e c t i o nof the State, b u t owing to its minnteness demanded ti larger scale p r ~ ~ j e c t i o to ~ i clearly distinguisli it tllau was requiratl for the precedi~lgedition. I n a geueral way and sullicient for illustrution me may explain t h e process of co~nputing and of prodncing systern:ttic results a s follows: The position of t h a t particular trigonometrical station most strongly with t h e maill triangulation is first fixed by adjustment, taking which i s co~inected into coilsideration the lines directed t o i t from primary stations a s well a s lines diverging from i t and intersecting t h e latter. Should tliere be more than one such point, say two or more, having equal strengtll of connection, they may be treated together in one least-square adjustment. I n this manner point after point or a series of fiuch is adjusted in position, so t h a t t h e sun1 of t h e squares of t h e corrections to tlie observed horizontal directior~sshL11 be a minimum; the geometrical relations of tlie preueding poi~itebeing always considered as fixed with respect to the variable clementreof t h e new point or points next under treatment. The principal secondtiry stations having tl~us beconlo knomn in position, t h e tertiary positions are determined in t h e same systematic, , tl~ongh ~onlewliat less elaborate, manner a s that followed for t l ~ secondaries, e and generally without least square adjustment.

The final result of this systematic treatment lnay be sulnmarized by stating that 110 discrepancy remains in the results themselves! and that the length aud direction of any aide of a triangle may bo computod from any starting side, and through any series of connecting triangles, and get the same results will be reached. The latitudes and longitudes of t,he trigonometric points wero computed by the usual formulile, aided by the tables ordinarily employed in the Survey, for wllich see Appendix No. 7, Report for 1884, but preferably tlie preceding Appendix No. 9 of this report. For primary sides, not excecdil~g ill length (s) 100 or 150 liilometres (about G2 or 93 statute miles), the formula for difference of latitude (AF), difference of longitude (AA), and difference of azimuth (Aa), are very accurate or sufficiently perfect for the purpose; these are:*

- Ag, = s cos a . B + s2sill2 a . C + ( 8 ~D )-~ 1~s2 sin2 a . E Ah = s sin a sec 9' . A - Aa = Ah sin a(q + sec $(Aq) + (LIA)~.F where - gg, = s cos a B + s2sin2 a C nearly
PI)

and h = s c o s a B hence tlie results for the new position

For sides not exceeding 25 or 30 kilolnetrcs (about 15 or 19 statute miles) the fourth term nl the expression for Ag, may Ije omitted, also tho factor sec $ (Aq), as well as tlie second term in the exprousion for A a . For full oxplanation, forms, examples, and auxiliary tables the reader may consult tho latest appendix cited above. There also is showr~ the inverso problem, viz, given q and h and p1and h' (or F, pl, and Ah) to find s and a and a'. This process ]nay be used i n cases where the required distance and azimuths a r e not directly co~itained in the table of results. of which 447 belong to the Borden aurvey. Of the occupied statioris 103 are Borden stations, and 43 are common to both surveys. A number of computers mas ol~gagedupon this work, but the priucipal share of the. work fell to Mr. E. H. Courtenay of the Computing Division, to whose zeal, industry, and scrupulous care much of the accuracy of the results IS clue. The results uom communicated were deduced in 1884,1885, 188671889718007 1891,1892, and 1894.
